Maria travels three times per week to regional markets where she buys grains, guinea pigs (a Peruvian delicacy), and pigs, which she then sells in the Ayacucho city markets as well as from her home. She sometimes slaughters the animals herself to sell for meat. Maria needs a loan of 1000 soles, which she will use to buy pigs and grains. 
Maria’s dreams are to have her own investment capital and to build a home of her own. 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Lirio. 
Maria es casada, tiene 42 años y 7 hijos, Maria viaja 3 veces a la semana a las ferias de la región en donde compran cereales, cuy, cerdos, que luego los comercializa en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho y también en su casa, en algunas oportunidades beneficia los animales. 
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerdo y cereales. 
Los sueños de Maria son tener capital propio para su negocio y construir su casa.

loans.use: Buy pigs and grains

loans.name: Mariela Sara

texts.es:
La señora Mariela pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Flores de Nuevo Edén ubicado en el PSJ. El Parque Mz. D Lt. 12, distrito de Yarinacocha, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo se dedica al manejo de una motokar. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. Tiene 5 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad cuenta con el mismo negocio. Tiene el apoyo de su hija para la atención de su negocio.  

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 8 kilos de arroz, 6 pollos, 4 racimos de plátanos, 2 kilos de azúcar, etc. 

Gracias al banco comunal su negocio ha crecido y gracias a ello su familia se siente contenta por todas las cosas que han logrado en la vida.
texts.en:
Mariela belongs to the Community Bank "Las Flores de Nuevo Eden" (meaning, The Flowers of New Eden) located at PSJ. El Parque Mz. D Lt. 12, in the district of Yarinacocha, in the province de Coronel Portillo in Ucayali. She is 35 years old, she is mother of 3 minor children who still depend on her. She is married and her husband drives a motorcycle taxi. With the first loan she received Manuela Ramos of S/.300 she decided to invest in food sales. She has been 5 years with the Community Bank.

She is still running the same business. She has her daughter's support in managing the business.

With this loan amounting to S/.1000, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will purchase 8 kg of rice, 6 chicken, 4 bunches of bananas, 2 kg of sugar, etc.

Thanks to the Community Bank her business has grown and thanks to this her family is happy for all of the things that have happened in their life.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 8 kg of rice, 6 chicken, 4 bunches of bananas, 2 kg of sugar, etc.

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma is a member of the Lirio (“Iris”) Village Bank. 
Irma is 56 years old and married with three children. She has a store in her home, located in the Jesús Nazareno District of Ayacucho where she sells dry goods. She runs the store in her free time and with the help of her daughter. She works full-time as a technician in the maternity ward of a local hospital. Irma plans to launch a new business selling juice and soda.  She needs a loan of 700 soles to remodel the space in which she plans to open her new store.  Irma dreams of expanding her business and for her children to get ahead in life, to finish school, and to become working professionals. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Irma es socia del Banco Comunal Lirio. 

Irma es casada, tiene 56 años y 3 hijos, Irma tiene una tienda en su casa ubicado en el distrito de Jesús Nazareno, en donde vende abarrotes, actividad que realiza en sus tiempos libres y con la ayuda de su hija. Irma trabaja como técnica en maternidad en el seguro. Irma tiene proyectado iniciar con un nuevo negocio de venta de jugos, gaseosas. 

Irma necesita un préstamo de 700 soles dinero que será invertido en la refacción del local para su nuevo negocio. 

Irma sueña con ampliar su negocio, que sus hijos salgan adelante, culminen sus estudios y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Remodel space to open a new store

loans.name: Merli Estrella

texts.es:
La señora Merli pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Solteritas, ubicado en el Jr. Grau Nº 192, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 34 años de edad y es soltera. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de manualidades. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad es profesora de Educación Inicial y cuenta con el mismo  negocio. En las mañanas trabaja como decente y por las tardes confecciona sus manualidades.  

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 10 metros de corrospú, 6 latas de terocal, un ciento de cartulinas, etc.

Merli manifiesta que todos sus logros es gracias a su esfuerzo y voluntad. Agradece a Dios por todo lo bueno que le ha pasado en la vida.
texts.en:
Merli belongs to the Community Bank "Las Solteritas" located in Jr. Grau No. 192 in the district Calleria within the province of Coronel Portillo in Ucayali. She is 34 years old and she is single. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 she decided to invest in the sale of craft. She has been with the Community Bank for the past 2 years.

With this loan, amounting to S/.1000, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase 10 metres of craft foam, 6 cans of glue, 100 sheets of construction paper, etc.

Merli says that all of her accomplishments are thanks to her efforts and will power. She thanks God for all the good that has come to her life.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 10 metres of craft foam, 6 cans of glue, and 100 sheets of construction paper, etc.

loans.name: Nora Ysabel

texts.es:
La señora Nora pertenece al Banco Comunal Pastaza, ubicado con la Av. Aviación Mz. B Lt. 1, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años de edad, es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo es independiente en su trabajo. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. Tiene 5 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de productos de bellezas (EBEL) y a la venta de comida. Ahora se encuentra delicada de salud, motivo por el cual ha dejado unos días la venta de alimentos. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,500, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 docenas de colonia, 6 cremas de manos, 8 lápices labiales y otros.  

Gracias a Manuela Ramos la estabilidad económica de su familia ha mejorado, y por ende tendrá la oportunidad de apoyar a sus pequeños hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nora belongs to the Pastaza Community Bank, located at Av. Aviación Mz. B Lt. 1 in the Callería district of the Coronel Portillo province in the department of Ucayali. Nora is 38 years old and the mother of two young children who depend on her. She's married and her husband has his own business. Nora used her first loan of 300 soles that she received from Manuela Ramos to invest in a food sales business. She has been working with the Community Bank for five years. Now Nora sells beauty products (EBEL) as well as food. Because she has recently had some health issues, Nora has decreased the number days that she sells food. With this loan of 2,500 soles, Nora will buy two dozen bottles of cologne, six hand creams, eight lip pencils, and others. Thanks to Manuela Ramos, Nora's family's economic stability has improved, and she'll have the opportunity to support her small children.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She'll buy two dozen bottles of cologne, six hand creams, eight lip pencils, etc.

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
La señora Reyna pertenece al Banco Comunal Pastaza ubicado con el Jr. 2 de Mayo Nº 196, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años de edad, es madre de un hijo mayor de edad, es casada y su esposo es independiente en su trabajo. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de gaseosas. Tiene 3 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad cuenta con el alquiler de Internet. Se dedica a la administración de su negocio, el cual le brinda ganancias para pagar su préstamo con puntualidad.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses lo invertirá en el arreglo y mantenimiento de sus maquinas de trabajo, las computadoras.

Reyna manifiesta que el esfuerzo de una mujer trabajadora y luchadora es valioso, por eso agradece al banco comunal por la ayuda que siempre le brinda.
texts.en:
Mrs. Reyna belongs to the Pastaza Community Bank, and she lives at Jr. 2 de Mayo Nº 196 in the Callería district of the Coronel Portillo province in the department of Ucayalo. She is 42 years old and has one son, who is grown up and married. Reyna's husband works independently. Reyna used her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos to invest in soft drink sales. She has been working with the community bank for three years. Now Reyna runs an internet cafe. She manages the business, which earns enough for Reyna to make her loan payments in a punctual manner. With this loan of 1,000 soles Reyna will invest in the maintenance and repair of her computers. She'll repay the loan in five months. Reyna believes that the efforts of a hard-working woman are valuable, and for this she thanks the community bank for the help that it always gives her.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She'll invest it in the maintenance and repair of the computers.

loans.name: Nicida

texts.en:
Nicida is a member of the Lirio (“Iris”) Village Bank. 
Nicida is 29 years old and separated with four children. She lives in her mother’s house and sells food from a mobile cart in the Magdalena market with the help of her mother. Nicida works each day from 7am to 2pm.  Nicida needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy rice, oil, grains, and sugar.  Nicida’s dreams are to have her own place in a fixed location where she can sell her products and for her children to grow up to be working professionals. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow


Nicida es socia del Banco Comunal Lirio. 
Nicida es separada, tiene 29 años y 4 hijos, Nicida vive en la casa de su mama, vende comida de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Magdalena, actividad que realiza desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 2 de la tarde, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda de su mama. 
Nicida necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, aceite, cereales y azúcar. 
Los sueños de Nicida son tener un puesto estable y propio, sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy rice, oil, grains, and sugar

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase goods such as tablecloths and bedspreads for resale

loans.name: Sara

texts.es:
La señora Sara pertenece al Banco Comunal Pastaza ubicado con PSJ. Abraham Valdelomar Mz. C Lt. 8 AAHH. Octavio Monteverde, distrito de Yarinacocha, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años de edad, es madre de 5 hijos, 3 mayores de edad y 2 que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja como mecánico de carros. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de comida. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio. En las mañanas se va al mercado a comprar lo necesario para preparar sus deliciosos platos de comida.  

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 5 kilos de arroz, 3 kilos de pescado, 2 kilos de carne, verduras y otros.  

Sara agradece al banco comunal porque su negocio ha mejorado. Gracias a sus ganancias tiene la oportunidad de darle a sus hijos una mejor educación.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sara belongs to the Pastaza Community Bank. She lives at PSJ. Abraham Valdelomar Mz. C Lt. 8 AAHH. Octavio Monteverde, in the Yarinacocha district of the Coronel Portillo province, in the department of Ucayali. Sara is 43 years old and the mother of five. Three of her children are grown and two still depend on her. Sara is married and her husband works as a car mechanic. Sara used her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos to invest in food sales. She has been working with the community bank for two years. Sara still manages her food sales business. In the mornings she goes to the market to buy the ingredients for her delicious dishes. With this loan of 1,800 soles, Sara will buy five kilos of rice, three kilos of fish, two kilos of meat, vegetables, and other items. Sara thanks the community bank because her business has improved. Thanks to her earnings she has the opportunity to give her children a better education.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sara will buy five kilos of rice, three kilos of fish, two kilos of meat, vegetables, and other items.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela is a member of the Lirio (“Iris”) Village Bank.  She is 60 years old, separated, and has seven children. She runs a stO. from her home in the Jesus Nazareno district of Ayacucho, where she sells dry goods, fruits, vegetables, and gifts. She works seven days a week, and her daughter helps her with the stO..  Adela needs a loan of 600 soles to buy rice and sugar.  Adela dreams that her children will have everything they need in life. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Adela Es socia del Banco Comunal Lirio.
Adela es separada, tiene 60 años y 7 hijos, Adela tiene una tienda en su casa, ubicada en el distrito de Jesús Nazareno, en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, frutas, artículos de regalos, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hija.
Adela necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar.
Adela sueña con que sus hijos tengan todo lo necesario en sus vidas.

loans.use: Buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Susana Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Susana pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Perseverantes ubicado en el  Jr. Yarinacocha Mz. B Lt. 15, distrito D. Yarinacocha, provincia D. Coronel Portillo, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 37 años D. edad, es madre D. 4 hijos menores D. edad que aún dependen D. ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja como contador para una empresa maderera. Con el primer préstamo que recibió D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300 deciD. invertir en la venta D. productos D. bellezas “UNIQUE”. Tiene 5 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad es profesora D. Educación Inicial y cuenta con el mismo negocio D. venta D. productos D. belleza, UNIQUE.    

Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará crema D. manos y cuerpo, loción, colonias, etc. 

Susana es una mujer que trabaja constantemente para darles una educación a cada uno D. sus hijos.
texts.en:
Señora Susana belongs to the community bank "Mujeres Perseverantes" located in the Jr. Yarinacocha Mz. B Lt. 15, district of Yarinacocha, province of Coronel Portillo, department of Ucayali. She is 37 years of age, is the mother of four young children who depend on her, is married, and her husband works as an accountant for a lumber company. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 Soles, she decided to invest it in the sale of "UNIQUE" beauty products. She has worked with the community bank for 5 years. Currently, she is an early education teacher and still counts on her business selling UNIQUE beauty products. With this loan of 1,500 Soles ($500), which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy hand and body cream, lotion, colognes, etc. Susana is a woman who works constantly to give an education to each of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase hand and body cream, lotion, colognes, etc.

loans.name: Aura Adilia

texts.es: La Señora Aura Adilia está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 6to crédito con AFODENIC para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda para terminar de repellar su casa y hecharle el piso a la cocina, trabaja como docente desde hace 7 años, tiene 3 hijos, el mayor de 12 años estudia su 6to grado de educación primaria, la otra niña tiene 6 añitos estudia su 1er grado y una bebe de 6 meses, su esposo es agricultor, trabaja cultivando la tierra en la finca en colonia San Antonio, ambos comparten los gastos del hogar.  Aura Adilia se caracteriza por ser una docente  responsable con sus deberes en su trabajo y en el hogar es por eso que es muy querida en su colonia por ser una mujer que ha demostrado ser humilde pero muy trabajadora  y muy querida  por sus alumnos y padres de familia, ella vive en la colonia San Antonio a 15 km de Nueva Guinea, esta clienta acaba de terminar de estudiar una licenciatura en ciencias de la Educación en la Universidad URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea. Ella se siente agradecida con la Institución de AFODENIC ya que con los créditos anteriores ha comprado electrodomésticos y a mejorado la vivienda donde ella vive, su sueño es  tener salud y estabilidad laboral.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aura Adilia is requesting refinancing for her sixth loan with Afodenic in order to improve her home and install flooring in her kitchen. She has been working as a teacher for the past seven years, and she has three children. The oldest one is 12 years old and is currently in sixth grade, the second one is 6 years old and she is studying in first grade, and the youngest one is 6 months old. Her husband works as a farmer in the San Antonio farm, and both of them contribute to the household expenses. Aura Adilia is very responsible with her duties both at work and at home, and that is why she is well liked in her neighborhood. She has been shown to be a humble and hardworking person, very loved by her students and family. She lives in the San Antonio farm, 15 kms from Nueva Guinea, and she just finished her Education studies in the University URACCAN in the Nueva Guinea precint. She is very thankful for the loans that she has received through Afodenic since those have allowed her to buy appliances and improve her home. Her dream is to be in good health and have job security.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha Cereceda, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve her home and install flooring in her kitchen.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restart a small business of selling underwear.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in large quantity of fresh meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Olga Angelica

texts.en:
Olga is a member of the Chiara Village Bank. 
She is 42 years old and married with two daughters. Olga and her sister raise and sell guinea pigs (a Peruvian delicacy). Olga has two sheds where she raises the guinea pigs and also has a plot of land where she grows alfalfa to feed them.  Olga needs a loan of 600 soles to buy alfalfa seed. Olga dreams of having her own business, that her son will study Business Administration, and of having some time for herself to relax.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Olga es socia del Banco Comunal Chiara.
Olga es casada, tiene 42 años y 2 hijas, Olga se dedica a la crianza y comercialización de cuyes, actividad que realiza con su hermana, Olga tiene 2 galpones de crianza, y terreno en el que siembra alfalfa para la alimentación de los cuyes, los cuyes los comercializa en los recreos.
Olga necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de semilla de alfalfa.
Olga sueña con tener una empresa, su hija estudie administración de empresas y tener un recreo propio.

loans.use: Buy alfalfa seeds to feed guinea pigs

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the Chiara Village Bank.  Rosa is 57 years old and married with nine children. She has a store in her house that faces a small plaza in the Chiara district where she sells dry goods, vegetables, fruits, and prepared meals. She works every day, and her daughter helps her with the store. Rosa also grows potatoes and corn.  Rosa needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy sugar and rice.  Rosa’s dreams are to sell a wider variety of merchandise at her store and proviD. her children with a good education. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Chiara. 
Rosa es casada, tiene 57 años y 9 hijos, Rosa tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en la plazoleta del distrito D. Chiara, en donD. venD. abarrotes, verduras, frutas, además venD. comida actividades que realiza todos los días con la ayuda D. su hija. Rosa también se dedica a la agricultura D. papa y maíz. 
Rosa necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. azúcar, arroz. 
Los sueños D. Rosa son surtir su tienda, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy sugar and rice

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is a member of the Chiara Village Bank. She is 27 years old and lives with her husband and their three children. Marina and her husband chop and sell firewood. Marina buys eucalyptus trees, which workers chop into firewood. The firewood is then brought to the city of Ayacucho and sold to bakeries that use wood-fired ovens. Marina also raises small animals, which she sells in her own district.  Marina needs a loan of 600 soles to buy eucalyptus trees.  Marina’s dreams are for her children to finish school, to have her own investment capital, and to expand her business. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Marina es socia del Banco Comunal Chiara. 
Marina es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 3 hijos, Marina junto a su esposo se dedican a hacer leña, Marina compra árboles de eucalipto que luego con la ayuda de peones realiza leña que transporta a la ciudad de Ayacucho y lo reparte a los hornos de panes. Además Marina se dedica a la crianza de animales menores que vende en su mismo distrito. 
Marina necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de árboles de eucalipto. 
Los sueños de Marina son que sus hijos culminen sus estudios, tener capital propio y hacer crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Buy eucalyptus trees

loans.name: Hak's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan that will be dispersed to five members.

Mrs. Hak C. is 32 years old and raises pigs for her income to sustain her family. She started her business in 2005 and can earn approximately US$5 each day. Her husband, Mr. Eang Lonh, 35, makes a living farming and specializes in rice and vegetables crops. They have four children, two of whom are in secondary school. Hak is seeking a loan of $200 to purchase food for her pigs. Hak leads an entrepreneurial group with four other members

Mrs. Samath S. is 30 years old and works as a rice farmer. She is asking for a $200 loan to buy more food for pigs.

Mrs. Sokhoeun C., 35, makes a living as a farmer and is also applying for a $200 loans to buy pig food.

Mrs. Sokhuor H. is 36 years old. She is a farmer who raises rice crops. Sokhuor needs $150 to purchase a female pig.

Mrs. Oeun M. is a 58-year-old widow who makes a living growing rice. She requests a loan of $200 to purchase a cow for plowing a field.

loans.use: Purchase food for pigs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to invest in her incense store

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao N., 57, is married and resides with her husband and two children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1987, she has been selling sugarcane in the market and is able to make US$3.50 per day, while her husband is a farmer and raises cows at home. Everyday, he just earns US$1. This couple also gets support from their children who work as construction workers. Both of them can make US$5 a day. Mao N. said on average she spends US$40 on food and US$15 on transportation. To make more money she would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase more sugarcane from individual growers for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more sugarcane.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum N., 36, is married and lives with four children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She and her husband together are cow dealers and make approximately US$5 each day. Her husband, Som Sokreun, also runs a motor-taxi around the market for extra profits to help support his family. Sum N. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to include with her savings to purchase more cows for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more cows

loans.name: Hien Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đinh Thị Hiền 43 tuổi tham gia vào Quỹ năm 1994. Các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ gia đình chị đều đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi, ban đầu do số vốn còn ít nên gia đình chị tập trung vốn vào đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn nái, chăn nuôi phát triển gia đình chị đã mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi ngoài chăn nuôi lợn nái gia đình chị còn nuôi thêm lợn thịt, gà và ngan. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi 30 con lợn thịt, 2 lợn nái, 200 con vừa gà và ngan thu nhập hàng năm từ chăn nuôi bình quân 40.000.000đ/ năm. Chị có 3 con, 1 con đang đi học, 2 con hiện đã đi làm thu nhập bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hien Thi D., 43 years old, joined the TYM fund in 1994. She used all the loans to invest in livestock. At first, when the loans were still small, she focused on raising female pigs. Later, she expanded the size of the farm, including male pigs, and poultry. At the moment, her family is taking care of 30 male pigs, 2 female pigs, and 200 poultry. The business brings in annual income of 40,000,000 Vietnamese Dong. She has 3 children, one of whom is still going to school. The other two are working and have an income of 3,000,000 Vietnamese Dong per month. She plans to make the next loan of 9,000,000 Vietnamese Dong to invest in more livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: invest in livestock

loans.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi: Chị Dương Thị Lành 50 tuổi tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương năm 1992. Trước khi trưa tham gia Quỹ kinh tế gia đình chị còn gặp nhiều khó khăn. Trải qua các vòng vốn kinh tế gia đình chị đã phát triển rõ rệt, gia đình chị đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi các loại như: Bò, lợn, gà, ngan, vịt. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang có 4 con bò, 200 con ngan, 100 con gà thịt, thu nhập từ chăn nuôi của gia đình chị bình quân mỗi năm 50.000.000đ. Chị có 4 con hiện các con chị đã trưởng thành và đã ra ở riêng, chồng chị cùng chị tham gia vào công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Chị Dương Thị Lành - 50 years old - joined the TYM Fund in 1992. Before the fund, her family was struggling financially. After getting through several loan cycles, her family's financial situation clearly improved. Her family invested in rearing livestock of many types, like cattle, pigs, chicken, and ducks. Currently, her family has 4 cows/bulls, 200 ducks, and 100 chicken. Their average income from rearing livestock is 50,000,000 VND annually. She has 4 good children. All of her children are grown and live on their own. Her husband helps her with the livestock rearing. For this loan cycle, she hopes to raise 15,000,000 VND to invest further in raising livestock. *cannot find translation

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Livestock

loans.name: Ul

texts.en: Ul N., 53, is married and lives with three children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers, growing rice. They also use their grinding mill to service the people in the area, to take off the rice husk. On average, they earn around US$15 combined in revenue per day. Ul N. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a tractor. This tractor will be hired to the local people to transport rice crops and goods for profit.

loans.use: To purchase a tractor.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị  Hải năm nay  44 tuổi, hiện cụi đang sống cùng chồng và  5 con tại xã Minh Phú huyện Sóc Sơn – Hà Nội. Năm 2000 chị  tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi.  Qua  8 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương  nhờ chăn nuôi hiệu quả nên kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng ổn định và phát triển. Hiện nay công việc chăn nuôi lợn, gà, ngan  đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng. Với nguồn thu nhập này ngoài việc hoàn trả vốn gia đình chị còn có thêm điều kiện để chi tiêu  và mua săm thêm các trang thiết bị cải thiện cuộc sống của gia đình. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hải is 44 years old. She is living with her husband and five children in the village of Minh Phú, Sóc Sơn District, Hà Nội (a.k.a. Hanoi). In 2000, she joined the fund and borrowed to invest in the business of rearing livestock. Because of their participation in TYM Fund for the past eight years and the good outcome of their livestock rearing business, her family's financial situation is better and continues to improve. Today, the business of raising pigs, chicken, and ducks provides the family with an income of 5,000,000 VND per month. With this income source, in addition to full repayment of their loans, the loan terms require the family to purchase household items to improve their living conditions. This loan cycle she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND to expand her livetsock rearing facilities/business. *cannot find translation

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Livestock

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Hong

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng M. năm nay 26 tuổi,chị mới tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2007. Hiện tại hai vợ chồngchị đều làm công việc kinh doanh. Chị mở cửa hàng kinh doanh mỹ phẩm, chăm sóc sắc đẹp cho chị em phụ nữ còn chồng chị mở cửa hàng kinh doanh cà phê. Công việc kinh doanh của hai vợ chồng chị đang phát triển rất thuận lợi và cho thu  nhập ổn định 4.000.000đ/ tháng
Chị Thu đang mong muốn được vay thêm 9.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn vào công việc kinh doanh của gia đình
texts.en:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng M. is 26 this year. She has been participating in the TYM Fund since 2007. Currently, she and her husband are both business people. She has a beauty salon - to help all women with their beauty needs. Her husband owns a coffee shop. Both of their businesses are growing quickly and provides a steady income of 4,000,000 VND per month. Chị Hồng is hoping to borrow another 9,000,000 VND to invest further into their family businesses.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay N., 58, is a widow and lives with eight children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She stays at home doing the house work and cooking for her family members. There is one child who has a business charging batteries. People who live in her village mostly depend on their batteries to power lighting, TV and radio. Another child is a rice miller and another makes rice wine.

Lay N. would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase a new generator for one of her children who has the business charging batteries.

loans.use: To purchase a new generator.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim T., 40, is married and lives with three children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She works at home breeding pigs and is able to make US$2.50 each day, while her husband is a farmer and horse-cart driver. He makes a combined US$5.50 per day. One of their children is a mechanic and one is a tailor. These two children also support the family with around US$100 each month. Kim T. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to invest in a new business. This money will be used to rent a banana farm.

loans.use: To rent banana farm.

loans.name: Zareena Malik Bashir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Zareena baji is the 45-year-old wife of M. B. A., and she resides in the city of Mumtazabad, which is famous for its holy places. In fact, she has lived in Mumtazabad for her entire life. She has one son, Javed, who completed his education through the 10th standard. Now, Javed works as a salesman in a vegetable market. Zareena baji’s husband is a driver by profession: he drives trucks loaded with various goods. More specifically, he delivers different items (such as vegetables and fruits) to different cities, and he has been in this business for the past 10 years.

Meanwhile, Zareena baji has a clothes-selling business, which she has operated for the past 7 years. Indeed, she collects clothes from the famous cloth markets of Lahore (“Ichra Bazaar and Anarkali”) and sells such clothes in her community for a profit. On average, she sells 15 suits per week, and she earns $8 to $10 by doing so. Notably, she has already successfully repaid two prior loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution of Pakistan. She is now applying for another loan to expand her clothes-selling business.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Shamim baji seeks a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop; Maqsoodan baji requests a loan to buy bed sheets to resell; Hakim baji is in need of a loan to buy vehicle wheels to resell; and Saima baji would like a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). In this way, this is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Importantly, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional clothes to resell

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị  Thảo 52 tuổi tham gia Quỹ năm 1994. Trải qua hơn 10 năm tham gia Quỹ vay vốn phát triển kinh tế. Các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ đều được gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà và ngan. Hiện tại gia đình chị đang nuôi 20 con lợn thịt, 100 con gà và ngan. Thu nhập từ chăn nuôi hàng năm của gia đình là 35.000.000đ, tới đây gia đình chị có kế hoach đầu tư vốn vào chồng rau và cây ăn quả, gia đình chị có 2 con, 1 đang đi học, 1 con đã đi làm lương tháng ổn định 2.000.000đ/ tháng, chồng chị đi làm thuê thu nhập 50.000đ/ ngày. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 13.000.000đ đầu tư vốn vào làm vườn.
texts.en:
Chị Phạm Thị Thảo - 52 years old - joined the TYM Fund in 1994. Participating in the program for over 10 years has transformed her financial situation. With every loan, her family put the funds towards raising pigs and chicken. Currently her family is raising 20 pigs and 100 chicken. The annual income from raising livestock is 35,000,000 VND. Now the family has the plan to get capital to grow fruits and vegetables. Her family has 2 children - 1 is in school and 1 is working with a steady salary of 2,000,000 VND per month. Her husband works as a hired hand for 50,000 VND per day. This loan cycle, the family is asking for 13,000,000 VND to invest in their garden.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Growing Fruits and Vegetables

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Đinh Thị S. năm nay 57 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương đã được 13 năm. Trong suốt quá trình tham gia Quỹ tình thương chị S. luôn sử dụng vốn vay rất hiệu quả, hoàn trả vốn đúng hạn và luôn chấp hành tốt mọi quy định của Quỹ. Hiện nay công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi . Với mức thu nhập hiện nay đạt khoảng 4.000.000đ/ tháng  gia đình chị ngày càng có điều kiện hơn để cải thiện cuộc sống và đầu tư cho các con ăn  học.
 Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm 1 con bò  sinh sản và 100 con gà  về chăn nuôi tăng thu nhập cho gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Đinh Thị S. is 57 years old. She has been a participant of the TYM Fund for 13 years. During her participation with the fund, Mrs. S. always gets good results from her loans and completely repays them punctually. And always does a good job of executing the organization's decisions and requests. Her family's current main source of income comes from rearing livestock. Their income is about 4,000,000 VND per month. Each day, her family's living standards gradually improve and they want to put money towards their children's educations. This loan cycle, she wants to borrow 9,000,000 VND to purchase more livestock to rear - 1 birthing cow and 100 chicken - to increase the family's income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To rear/ raise cow and chicken

loans.name: Chen

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Chén năm nay 54 tuổi, gia đình chị có 5 con đều đã trưởng thành. Tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1994 chị Chén  xin vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Đến năm 2005, nhờ kinh tế gia đình phát triển chị đã đầu tư mua được máy say sát gạo phục vụ cho nhu cầu của bà con địa phương. Hiện  nay với mức thu nhập 5.000.000đ từ chăn nuôi, làm máy sát gạo và lương của chồng kinh tế gia đình  chị Chén đang ngày càng phát triển hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mongm uốn được vay 8.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà.
texts.en:
Ms. N. Thi Chen is 54 years old. Her family has 5 children, all are grown. Joining TYM fund in 1994, she borrowed money to invest in raising pigs. In 2005, thanks to improved family income, she was able to purchase a machine to grind rice for the local community. Presently, with income from raising pigs at 297 USD, rice grinding and her husband's salary, her family's income is improving every day. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 475 USD to invest in raising pigs and chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business and raising pigs and chickens

loans.name: Hoa

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hoà năm nay 61 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1994 đến nay qua 15 năm sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả kinh tế gia đình chị Hoà đã có sự thay đổi rõ rệt. Hiện tại với mức thu nhập từ chăn nuôi 3.000.000đ/ tháng và sự hỗ trợ của các con đã đi làm kinh tế gia đình chị Hoà đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong  muốn 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm bò, lợn, gà về chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms, N. Thi Hoa is 61 years old; her family has 3 grown children. She joined TYM fund in 1994 and for the past 15 years, she has seen visible improvement in her family's income from utilizing the loan program. Presently, with income of 180 USD per month from raising farm animals and assistance from her children who are employed, her family's income is getting more and more stable every day. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 900 USD to purchase additional cows, pigs and chickens to raise

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising farm animals

loans.name: Yean

texts.en: Yean S., 27, is married and lives with her husband and her children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She and her husband work together making house ladders in the village. On average, they earn a combined US$3 each day. This business has been around for four years. To increase their productivity, Yean S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase sand, cement, rock and other materials to make more ladders. The photo is of Yean's husband as she was not available at the time the photograph was taken.

loans.use: To purchase sand, cement, rock and other materials to make more ladders.

loans.name: Vui

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Vui 38 tuổi tham gia vào Quỹ năm 1994, nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị hiện tại là kinh doanh buôn bán, chồng chị là các bộ nhà nước lương tháng ổn định. Vốn vay của Quỹ đều được chị đầu tư vào buôn bán, gia đình chị chủ yếu tập chung vào kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa, thức ăn gia súc và phân bón phục vụ bà con trong vùng. Với thuận lợi có nhiều mặt hàng đa dạng phù hợp với nhu cầu của bà con quanh địa phương nên số lương khách hàng của gia đình chị rất đông, bình quân mỗi ngày gia đình chị thu lợi nhuân là 250.000đ từ việc kinh doanh, chị có 3 con hiện đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư vốn vào kinh doanh.
texts.en:
Ms, N. Thi Vui is 38 years old and joined TYM fund in 1994. Her family's main source of income at the present time is from commerce. Her husband is a government employee with stable monthly income. She had always invested the prior loans into her grocery store, selling miscellaneous merchandise, food items, fertilizer to serve the local community, Because of the multitude of merchandise available in her store as well as customers' demands, she has a lot of customers, bringing in average 15 USD daily from her store. She has 3 children who are of school age. For this next loan, she wishes to borrow 900 USD to invest in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her grocery store

loans.name: Kllong

texts.en: Kllong D., 56, has a business selling porridge and Khmer cake from her house to earn a living, and is able to make US$4 a day. She is a widow and has five of her seven children. Four children are employed as workers. Kllong D. is asking a loan of US$500 to set up a small tailoring shop for one of her daughters.

loans.use: To set up a tailor shop.

loans.name: Thu

texts.vi:
Chị Tạ Thị Thu năm nay 26 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tìnhthương từ đầy năm 2007. Hiện nay công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình  chị là từ  buôn bán quần áo. Ngoài thu nhập từ buôn bán  hàng tháng gia đình  chị còn có thêm nguồn thu nhập từ lương thợ xây của chồng nên kinh tế rất ổn định. Với mức thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng cuộc sống của gia đình chị Thu đang ngày càng được cải thiện hơn.
 Vòng vốn tới chị Thu mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn vào công việc kinh doanh quần áo
texts.en:
Ms. T. Thi Thu is 26 years old. She joined TYM fund in 2007. Her family's main source of income at the present time is from her clothing store. In addition to her clothing store, she has additional income from her husband's job as a construction worker, and thus her family's income is very stable. With an average income of 245 USD per month, her family's life is improving every day. For this next loan, she wishes to borrow 550 USD to invest in her clothing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Thok

texts.en: Thok C., 40, is married and lives with her husband and two of her three children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She works growing bamboo to earn a profit and is able to make US$1.60 per day. Her husband Prum Chuk, 41, is a cow dealer and makes US$4 each day. She would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a horse and its cart for her son to run a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and its cart.

loans.name: Yasmeen Saleem Akhtar Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen A. baji is 40 years old, and she resides in the city of Mumtazabad in Pakistan. She completed her education through the 5th standard, but she was unable to receive additional schooling because her father did not generate sufficient income to continue to send her to school. Yasmeen baji’s husband, S. A., is a driver (he drives an auto-rickshaw, a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). In addition, they have six children: two sons and four daughters. Her oldest daughter helps her mother make quilts (a kind of blanket), while her other children are students.

After completing her education, she learned the skill of quilt-making from her mother. Thereafter, she started a business of making quilts for her neighbors. Notably, Yasmeen baji has already successfully repaid two prior loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution of Pakistan. Now she is applying for another loan to expand her business; in particular, she would like to buy materials (e.g., cloth, cotton, needles, and threads) to meet her customers' demands. In fact, this is the winter season, so she points out that her services are in high demand.

She is joined in her loan group by five other members: Shamshad baji seeks a loan to buy more clothes to resell; Kaniza mai baji, Tahira batool baji, and Asia baji each request a loan to buy materials (e.g., clothes, sketches, and colored thread) to make dresses to display in their boutiques; and Riffat baji would like a loan to buy foodstuffs (e.g., chips and cookies) for her canteen. In this way, this is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Importantly, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To capitalize on high demand by purchasing additional materials to make more quilts

loans.name: Eun

texts.en: Eun T., 50, is married and has a business selling groceries and some vegetables from her house to earn a living, and is able to make US$7 in revenue each day. Her husband is a fisherman and makes US$3 a day. This couple also gets support from two of their children who work at Phnom Penh as garment factory workers. She would like to take out a loan of US$500 to add to her grocery inventory to attract more customers.

loans.use: To add to her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Loun

texts.en: Loun S., 36, is a teacher and a farmer. Her husband works raising fish and farming as well. This couple earns around US$3 of profit combined each day. Farming by depending on the sky is unreliable and sometimes they face crop damage because of lack of water. To escape this problem, Loun S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a water pump. This machine will be used to hire to people for extra profit as well. Loun's husband is pictured in the photograph as the borrower was not available when the photo was taken.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump.

loans.name: Rubina M.javed Group

texts.en:
Rubina Javed is the wife of M., and they live in the city of Mumtazabad in Pakistan, which is famous for its holy places and its friendly people. They own a two-room, brick house, which they have lived in for the past 11 years. In addition, they have two children: one son and one daughter. Her son is in the 8th standard, and her daughter is in the 4th standard. Her husband is a salesman of food products such as nimko and chips.

Meanwhile, Rubina baji has her own boutique where she displays and sells her collection of different kinds of clothes (e.g., simple, stitched clothes as well as intricate, embroidered clothes). She has been in this line of business for 9 years. Notably, Rubina baji has already successfully repaid two prior loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. Now she is applying for another loan to buy additional materials (e.g., cloth, colored thread, and sketches) for her boutique.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Kosar Parveen baji seeks a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable-selling business; Shamim Akhtar baji requests a loan to buy more clothes for her clothes-selling business; Fariha naz baji is in need of a loan to buy the same materials Rubina Javed is seeking (cloth, colored thread, and sketches) for her boutique; and Shamim baji would like a loan to buy bed sheets to resell. In this way, this is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Importantly, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional materials in order to make more dresses

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng C., 52, is a widowed farmer and makes less than one dollar per day. She has five children, two of whom are garment workers. She is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a tractor to plow her farmland. This tractor will be used to hire to the people in the village for extra profit to support the family as well.

loans.use: To purchase tractor.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum N., 26, is married and lives with one of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers and rice sellers who typically make about US$10 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Sum N. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more rice from individual growers to resell. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase rice for sale.

loans.name: Noeng

texts.en: Noeng S., 48, is married and lives with six children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband have a business catching fish from the river which is near their house. They always sell their catch at the market to earn approximately US$5 of profit each day. This couple also get support from two of their children who work at Phnom Penh as garment factory workers. Noeng S. would like to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase more fishing tools. This will allow this couple to catch more fish for sale.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools.

loans.name: Keng

texts.en: Keng S., 26, resides in the Kampong Cham with his old mother and one brother who works as a soldier. Since 2006, he has been working as a taxi-driver to earn a living and is able to make US$3 each day, while his mom, Chhouk Kan, 60, stays at home selling soft drinks. She makes around US$1.50 per day. Currently, the car is broken so Keng S. would like to take out a loan of US$250 to fix his car.

loans.use: To repair the car.

loans.name: Fakhira Gul Hamid-Ul-Lah Khan Group

texts.en:
Fakhira Gul baji resides in the city of Mumtazabad in Pakistan, where she has lived for the past 15 years. She is the wife of H. K., and they have three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a driver (he drives an auto-rickshaw, a three-wheeled motor vehicle), her younger son is in the 8th standard, and her daughter is in the 6th standard. Her husband is also a driver, and he too drives an auto-rickshaw.

Meanwhile, Fakhira Gul baji has an embroidery business, and she has been in this line of business for the past 6 years. Specifically, she makes embroidered clothes and later sells such clothes for a profit at different shops for $10 to $12 per suit. Notably, she has already successfully repaid two prior loans from Asasah, a microfinance institution in Pakistan. Now she is applying for another loan to buy materials (e.g., colored thread, sketches, and needles) to expand her embroidery business.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Zahida Akhtar baji seeks a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business; Naseem baji requests a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw; Shahnaz baji is in need of a loan to buy bed sheets to resell; and Tajan baji would like a loan to buy plastic beans to sell in factories. In this way, this is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Importantly, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional raw materials

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Ban S., 31, is married and lives with four young children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer, growing rice, and typically makes US$3 each day, while her husband is a fisherman and soldier. On average, he makes US$2 a day. Two of their children are students and the two others are too young to attend school.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Ban S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase fertilizer for their farm, a purchase that she believes can bring an increase to her daily income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for their farm.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng C., 28, is married and lives with her two children in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making less than US$1 each day, while her husband works as a police officer. Her husband makes about US$1 each day. They also support an older mother at home. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gone out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also been a factor in making the price of rice very high.

Heng C. is asking for a loan of US$300 to add to her grocery inventory. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To add to her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Theap

texts.en: Theap S., 36, is a widowed food seller who lives in the Kampong Cham province with two school-aged children. She typically makes US$10 each day. Besides selling food, she also raises ducks to help support her family. Currently, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase feed for ducks. This will help ducks to lay more eggs. So far, there are about 40,000 ducks at her farm.  In the future, if she has enough money, she will expand her business by adding more ducks to increase her livestock.

loans.use: To purchase feed for ducks.

loans.name: Teang

texts.en: Teang B. R. is married and lives with her three children and husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been working as a tailor to earn a living and is able to make US$13 in revenue a day, while her husband works selling grocery products and is able to make US$16 in revenue a day. All of their children are students. Teang B. R. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to add more groceries to attract more customers.

loans.use: To add groceries

loans.name: Cham

texts.en: Cham S., 42, is married and lives with her four children and husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2007, she has been raising ducks for eggs to earn a living and is able to make US$7.50 per day. Her husband is a farmer growing rice. The climate conditions have been unfavorable in Cambodia this past year for farming, and this has caused food prices to soar. Inflation has also been out of control, as this has turned into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Cham S. included. Mrs. Cham S. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to expand her livestock by adding more ducks and purchase feed for them as well.

loans.use: To expand her livestock.

loans.name: Utkir

texts.en:
A. Utkir is 28 years old, married and has two kids. Utkir was born and raised in Shahristan, Tajikistan, where he cultivates wheat and different kinds of vegetables. He has worked in agriculture for many years and gained much experience. Utkir's large family helps him with his business. He lives with his parents, brothers, and sisters. Utkir dreams of having his own house as his children are growing up. He worries about their future. 

He will invest his loan of 500 (150 USD) in buying fuel, lubricants, and bags for the upcoming potato planting season. With the help of a loan he can earn more income and make his dreams come true.

loans.use: to purchase bags, fuel, and lubricants

loans.name: Zarif

texts.en: Zarif has a very large family. He is married with 5 children. His special interest is mechanical engineering but he has been running a farming business for 7 years. Zarif has been an active and strongly motivated client of IMON since August 2007. He has received and paid back loans from IMON for twice. His credit history makes him eligible to receive new and larger loans. Zarif is a very good family man who loves his family and wants a good future for them. He is dreaming to raise his children, to give them higher education so that someday they’ll become successful entrepreneurs. His beloved wife does whatever she can to help him and together they have decided to increase the number of crops they plant so that they can generate a larger income. They will invest this loan for purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for the upcoming season of growing potato. In order to do this, Zarif is requesting a loan of 500 Somoni (150 USD), which he is committed to repaying over a period of 9 months. He appeals to your generosity so that he can begin this family project.

loans.use: Purchasing of the seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Sarah J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Sarah C. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, aged between 3 and 19. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 4 dependents because their parents died of HIV.

Sarah has been running a tailoring business since 1990. Her business is repairing clothes and making dresses and trousers. She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Currently she earns about $142 from her business.

She is requesting a loan of $650 in order to buy clothing material in bulk for making more clothes. In the future, she plans to enlarge the tailoring shop. Sarah thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy clothing material in bulk for making more clothes

loans.name: Lafiz

texts.en:
G. Lafiz is 38 years old, married and has three children. He has a secondary education and operates an animal husbandry business. He has a small farm where he breeds calves. Because he does not have a specialized education, animal husbandry is the only source of income for his family. Lafiz buys calves on the market at a low price, feeds them, and then resells them at a higher price. 

Lafiz is applying for a loan because he needs money to buy more cattle. He is requesting 2500 Somoni (750 USD) and plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: to purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Janu

texts.en:
Junu P. is a married woman and lives in Bhakepati, Nepal. Bhakepati is located in the Kathmandu district where most of the people are farmers.

Mrs. P. lives in a single-family home with her husband and three children, two daughters and one son. Her oldest daughter is in grade 7, her youngest daughter is in grade 4, and her son is in primary school. Her husband's name is Mr. Ram P., and he is a carpenter.

Mrs. P. started raising goats 5 years ago and currently has 5 goats. She sells her goats at the local meat shop. This business has allowed her to improve her life, and she no longer needs to ask her husband for money. Mrs. P. is requesting a loan of Rs 15000.00 ($200.00) to buy a few more goats.

loans.use: Buy more goats

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase various goods to stock a small store.

loans.name: Vumilia I.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Vumilia M. from Mbeya. She is a widow with no children. She is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are orphans.

Vumilia has been running a genge business since 2002. Her business is buying tomatoes, rice, and fish and selling them at higher prices. She works at the business for 4 hours per day, 3 days per week. Currently she earns about $100 from her business.

She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy more rice, fish, and tomatoes in bulk. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Vumilia thanks you for your support!

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more rice, fish, and tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Elvila L.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Elvila N. from Mbeya. She is a widow with 4 children, aged between 30 and 24. Elvila has been running a local restaurant known as a “mama lishe” since 2000. Her business is buying items like rice, maize flour, beans, and meat and then preparing them for a meal and selling food.

She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Elvila currently earns about $215 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy more rice, flour, and beans for food. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Elvila thanks you for your support!

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more rice, flour, and beans

loans.name: Anu

texts.en:
Mrs. Anu B. is a tailor in the village of Bhakepati, Kathmandu. She lives with her husband, son, and daughter. Both of her children are in pre-school. Her husband, Mr. Suresh B., went to Dubai for work

Mrs. B. opened her tailoring shop 6 years ago. Before starting her own business, Mrs. B. took a 3- month training course from a tailor shop near her home. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies' dresses, like the Kurta Sulwar, which is very popular among Nepali women.

She plans to use the loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150.00) to buy tailoring materials for her business. She wants to use the shop's income to improve her family's standard of living and for her children's education.

loans.use: Buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Magreth G.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Magreth M. from Mbeya. She is a widow with 4 children, between the ages of 19 and 25. Magreth has been running a local restaurant business since 2001.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by 1 employee and her brother. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to purchase additional stock. In the future, she plans to open another business. Magreth thanks you for your support!

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Uma

texts.en:
Mrs. Uma B. is a resident of Bhatkepati, Nepal and lives in a single-family home with her husband and daughter. Her husband, Mr. Pradeep B., works in a private office, and her daughter is in pre-school.

Mrs. Uma B. started her poultry farm two years ago in the hopes of improving her family's standard of living. She has 2000 chickens on her farm. The cost of one small chicken is Rs 35.00, which she raises for 50 days before selling it at the local market. Mrs. B. is requesting a loan of Rs 15000.00 ($200.00) to buy more chickens and grain to feed the chickens.

loans.use: Buy more chickens

loans.name: Minu

texts.en:
Mrs. Minu S. is a resident of Wolkhu, Lalitpur, and attends the microfinance group meeting in Tangal, which is only five minutes away from Wolkhu.  She lives with her husband, son, and daughter. Most of the people in this area are engaged in business. Her daughter is in grade 11, and her son is in grade 6.

Both Mr. and Mrs. S. are engaged in their own business. For 8 years they have make papads, colorful chips, snacks, and pickles in their own home, which they sell in grocery shops. Their snacks have become very popular. Mrs. S. is requesting her fifth loan of Rs 30000.00 ($400.00) to purchase more ingredients for their business.

loans.use: Ingredients for snacks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in cell phone calling cards to resell

loans.name: Junu

texts.en:
Mrs. Junu T. lives in Kritpur, Nepal. Kritpur is located in the Kathmandu district, where most of the people are engaged in small businesses. Mrs. T. lives in a single-family home with her husband and son. Her husband, Mr. Santa Bahadur, is a rickshaw driver, and her son is in primary school.

Junu T. has a grocery store in Kritpur where she sells different types of groceries. She is planning to sell vegetables in her grocery store in the hopes of increasing her income. Mrs. T. is requesting a loan of Rs 10000.00 ($150) to buy vegetables and racks.

loans.use: Buy vegetables

loans.name: Kalpana

texts.en:
Mrs. Kalpana P. lives in Kritpur, Kathmandu. She lives with her husband, Mr. Prem Kumar P., her two daughters, and son. Her husband is a carpenter, and her children are in higher secondary school.

Mrs. P. opened a grocery shop 10 years ago to improve her family's standard of living. She sells different types of groceries such as rice, maize, snacks and green vegetables.

Due to a lack of funds, she can’t buy goods for her shop. Mrs. P. is asking for a loan of Rs 20000.00 ($275.00) to buy goods like rice, dhal, and noodles. She wants to use her income to provide a better education for her children and to help her husband improve the quality of their lives.

loans.use: Buy grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Mirembe Mariam ’S Group

texts.en: Miriam is a leader of 5 members of a group.  She is 35 and married with 6 children aged between 5 and 18 years. All her children go to school.  Miriam takes care of her old parents. She resides and owns a three-roomed house where she is staying with five people.  They have electricity and piped water at home. The family gets two meals a day and rarely take tea.  Miriam works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala, dealing in second-hand towels and bed sheets   She uses public transport to and from work.  Miriam buys these items from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city.  She sells to an average of 20 customers per day. Besides linens, she also sells airtime. Miriam sells to all categories of people and has been in this business for five years, working six days a week. She is faced with a challenge of seasonality and medication expenses. She has been with MCDT for four years working all with the same group mates and wants to use this loan to have permanent place to sell her merchandise. and she aspires to educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To acquire  permanent business premises

loans.name: Socheata

texts.en:
Mrs. Socheata U. is a villager in Koh Ras Leu Village in Kandal Province. She is a teacher who earns a small income to support the family. 

Her husband, Mr. Hut Sothun, is a lottery seller. They have three children who are all attending the local school. 

Although Mrs. Socheata U. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot afford to build a new house, so Mrs. Socheata U. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to build a new house for her household. 

Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings in order to build a new house for her household.

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en:
Mrs. Shanti M. is 31 years-old and lives in Kritpur, Kathmandu. She lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Ram Kumar M., works in a finance office, and her son is in grade 7.

Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop 2 months ago where she sells different types of groceries. Due to a lack of money, she cannot purchase goods for her shop. Mrs. Shanti seeks a loan of Rs10000 ($150) to buy necessary goods like rice, bitten rice, different kinds of pulses, noodles, and biscuits to sell in her shop.

loans.use: Buy grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Sam Or

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Or T. is a tailor in Koh Ras Leu Village in Kandal Province. In this business, she faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to purchase a sewing machine in order to make clothes for her customers. 

She hopes to make better quality clothes for her consumers with this loan. Mrs. Sam Or T. is a 53-year-old widow with four children, one of whom is a teacher who earns a small salary to support the family while the remaining three are attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine in order to make clothes for her customers.

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mrs. Ret I. lives in Prey Khduoch Village in Takeo Province. She is farmer who owns a small plot of land to cultivate rice to earn living. 

Her husband, Mr. Nhem Chea, is a motorbike taxi driver who earns a small income to support the family. Although they have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well.  

Thus, Mrs. Ret I. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding, and she hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow.

Mrs. Ret I. is 57 years old and the mother of three children: One is a cassette player repairer, another is an ice-cream seller and the remaining one is a farmer. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Meletia H.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 52-year-old Meletia K. from Mbeya. She is a widow with 4 children, between the ages of 20 and 30. Meletia has been running a genge business since 1992. Her business is to purchase commodities wholesale and sell them retail to people around the area.

She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Meletia currently earns about $80 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $650 in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, and fish. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Meletia thanks you for your support!

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, and fish

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambath N. is a villager in Traov Em Village in Takeo Province. She is a breeder who raises chickens and pigs. 

Since her businesses are going well, she wants to expand, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more chickens and two piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Touch Chanthorn, is a farmer who has a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. 

Mrs. Sambath N. is 50 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is electrician while the youngest one is attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and two piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok H. is a farmer in Andoung Thmor Village in Takeo Province. She usually gets rice revenue every January. 

Her husband, Mr. Sem Thol, is a cow breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding. 

Mrs. Sok H. is 41 years old and the mother of five children: Three are employed in a garment factory while the remaining two are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy one more cow for breeding.

loans.name: Flavia C.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Flavia K. from Mbeya. She is married with 4 children, between the ages of 5 and 15. Flavia has been running a tailoring business since 1998. Her business is to make clothes for her customers.

She works at the business for 4 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her daughter. She currently earns about $50 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase additional stocks of clothes and materials for making more clothes. In the future, she plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothes and materials for making more clothes

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa C. is a villager in Kraing Boteay Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. 

Her husband, Mr. Pom Ngan, is a cow breeder who raises cows to sell. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it, so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy two more cows for breeding. 

Mrs. Channa C. is 33 and does not have any children. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for breeding.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase sacks of cocoa to retail outside her community.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny P. lives in Phnom Lontas Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small rice field to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Nop Vanna, is a teacher who earns a small salary to support the family.

Although Mrs. Vanny P. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding, and she hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. 

Mrs. Vanny P. is 50 years old and the mother of two children, who are both enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding and increasing her income.

loans.name: Lauth A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Lauth M. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 14 and 18. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents whose parents died of HIV.

Lauth has been running a small shop since 2007. Her business is purchasing items wholesale and selling them retail. She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Lauth currently earns about $150 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy soda, wheat flour, rice, and groundnuts. In the future, she plans to expand and establish another business. Lauth thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy soda, wheat flour, rice, and groundnuts

loans.name: Ramzan M.aslam Group

texts.en:
Ramzan baji is a 42-year-old lady who resides in the city of Shah Rukn in Pakistan, a place famous for its shrines and hand-made items. Ramzan baji is a very hardworking lady who believes in herself; indeed, her determination was what brought her from poverty to prosperity. Ramzan baji is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son works at a gas station, while her younger son is in the 6th standard. As for her daughters, her elder daughter helps her make embroidered dresses for clients, while her younger daughter is in the 8th standard.

Ramzan baji operates a clothes-selling business. She began her career as a seamstress (she stitched various designed clothes), and eventually she started taking orders from the people of her community. She has 10 years worth of experience in this business. Now Ramzan baji is applying for a loan in order to buy a machine which will help her make more embroidered clothes and which will in turn enable her to generate more profits.

She is joined in her loan group by five other members: Naziran baji seeks a loan to buy a washing machine for her laundry business; Muniran baji wants a loan to repair her truck; Razia baji requests a loan to buy various goods (e.g., lentils, cooking oil, and spices) for her food business; Nasreen baji is in need of a loan to buy products (e.g., plastic bottles and waste paper) for her scrap business; and Samina baji would like a loan to buy medicine for her medical store. In this way, this is a group loan; as such, the loan proceeds will be distributed amongst the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Notably, the group members mutually guarantee one another's loans; as a result, if one group member does not repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears.

loans.use: To increase her business' output (of embroidered clothes) by purchasing a machine

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna K. is a villager in Pong Ro Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. 

Since her field is far from irrigation, she does not have a way to generate water to water her plants. Thus, Mrs. Vanna K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump to water her crop. 

Her husband, Mr. Nut Dem, is a fisherman who gathers a little fish to support the family. Mrs. Vanna K. is 46 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a pump to water her crop.

loans.name: Mary M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 52-year-old Mary M. from Mbeya. She is a widow with 1 child, age 32. Mary has been running a shop since 2006. Her business is selling items like rice, maize flour, cooking oil, salt, etc.

She works at the business for 16 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her sister-in-law and 1 daily worker. Mary currently earns about $177 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to purchase more items in bulk for resale. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mary thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more items in bulk

loans.name: Dear

texts.en:
Mrs. Dear U. lives in Pong Ro Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who has a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. 

Her husband, Mr. Son Kheourt, is a poultry breeder who raises ducks. Since his ducks now have a lot of ducklings, he does not have enough money to buy duck food to feed them. Thus, Mrs. Dear U. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. 

Mrs. Dear U. is 22 years old and the mother of a 4-year-old child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy duck food to feed his ducks.

loans.name: Toy

texts.en:
Mrs. Toy A. is a farmer in Pong Ro Village in Takeo Province. She cannot plant this season because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed to cultivate.
