Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed to plant rice. Her husband, Mr. Lim Phouk, owns a rice mill through which he can generate income. 

Mrs. Toy A. is 42 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seed to plant rice.

loans.name: Sakina Ghulam Rasool Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a 54-year-old lady and has lived in a city named Shah Rukn, Pakistan for the past 50 years. Sakina baji’s husband is G. R. and he is a mason. She has four sons.Two sons are cobblers and make shoes, and the other two are daily wage laborers. Sakina baji has been a hardworking seamstress for the past 20 years. She charges $2 to $3 for her services and successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (leather, nails and shoe polisher) to expand her sons' shoe making business.  

She is joined in her loan group by: Tasleem baji who requests a loan to buy more clothes to sell for her business;  Zareena baji who requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop; Nasreen Akhtar baji who requests a loan to buy a motor bike for her motor bike rental business; and  Afshan baji who requests a loan to buy plastic bottles and papers for her scrap business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for shoe making

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov K. is a villager in Pong Ro Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who has a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Leang Tiey, owns a small rice mill through which he can earn income. 

Although they have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well. Thus, Mrs. Pov K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to buy a motorbike to start a motorbike taxi business. 

Mrs. Pov K. is 36 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To add to her savings in order to buy a motorbike to start a motorbike taxi business.

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en:
Mr. Vuthy  C. is a villager in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. He is a construction worker who can earn a small income to support the family. His wife, Mr. Pov Srey Neang, is a farmer who has a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. 

Although he and his wife have different businesses, they still cannot improve their living conditions. Thus, Mr. Vuthy  C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding, and he hopes to increase his income after he sells the cow. 

Mr. Vuthy  C. is 23 and does not have any children. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira G. is a widow with three children. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Khodjali region. Elmira is settled in the Absheron region.

Elmira has a business and needs 970 AZN to buy wares to improve the business.

loans.use: To buy wares

loans.name: Loem

texts.en:
Mrs. Loem H. lives in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who can earn a little rice revenue because she owns a small rice field. Her husband, Mr. Ngov Seourng, is a rice wine maker in the local village. 

Although Mrs. Loem H. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well, so Mrs. Loem H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. 

Mrs. Loem H. is 39 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the remaining two are too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock a grocery store.

loans.name: Severina

texts.en:
As a mother, Severina M., a 45-year old resident of Basak, Loon, Bohol, always wants the best for her 5 children. She desires to change her life and build a good future for her kids by paying more attention to how she could run her business well. Now, she operates a “carenderia” (food stall) in front of their house with her husband helping her run the business. From her earnings, she was able to send 3 of her children to secondary school.

She is requesting her first loan of PHP 6,000 from CEV to purchase additional ingredients and food items to expand her business.

“With my loan, I could compete well with other food stalls, and attract more customers,” she uttered with confidence.

By joining the program of CEV, she has access to credit, trainings, and insurance services that she believes could help improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buying ingredients and food items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sadeta

texts.en:
Sadeta was born in 1951 and she lives in Klokotnica, a village in Bosnia.  She lives with her husband and with their two adult sons, both of whom are employed.  She is a housewife, but she also grows vegetables in a garden and takes care of two cows, whose milk she sells in the market.  

She is requesting a loan of 600KM ($400 USD) from Women for Women International to purchase food for her two cows.  She hopes that she will be able to continue raising cows for a long time because “this work makes her happy.”

This loan is guaranteed by Subhija Džebić.

loans.use: To purchase food for cows

loans.name: Ngoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngoem S. is a farmer in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. On her plantation, she now faces an obstacle, because she does not have enough animals to plow the fields to cultivate rice. 

In order solve this problem, Mrs. Ngoem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a buffalo to add to the one she now owns to plow the field. Her husband, Mr. Tes Muth, helps her on the plantation. 

Mrs. Ngoem S. is 47 years old and the mother of three children who are all employed in a garment factory. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo to add to the one she owns to plow the field.

loans.name: Tasleem Zahida Mushtaq Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Tasleem Zahida baji is a wife of M. A. and resides in a city named Shah Rukn, Pakistan. Shah Rukn city is  famous for its shrines and hand-made items. Tasleem is 30 years old, mother of six (five sons and one daughter) and owns her own two-room, brick house. Her daughter helps her in her decorative embroidering business. Her elder son works in his father’s spare parts shop where he sells bicycles spare parts. The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Tasleem baji makes decorative clothes on order. She is requesting a loan to buy more bicycle spare parts for her husband’s shop. 

She is joined in her loan group by a the following members: Parveen baji requests a loan to buy material (leather and nails) for her shoe making business. Ghazala baji requests a loan to buy edible items (nimko, chips and cookies) for her canteen. Ghulam Fatima baji requests a loan to buy material (cloth, colored thread and sketches) for her boutique. Kosar parveen baji requests a loan to buy (flour) for her bread making business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy bicycles spare parts

loans.name: Magreth M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Magreth M. from Mbeya. She is married with 4 children, between the ages of 12 and 23. Magreth has been running a charcoal business since 1995. Her business is to buy charcoal from the village wholesale and sell it retail to consumers in town.

She works at the business for 16 hours per day, 6 days per week. Magreth currently earns about $200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to purchase more charcoal in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Magreth thanks you for your support!

These small, black, and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to charcoal sellers but to their customers, who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal), and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame, and makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Malim

texts.en: Mrs. Malim L. is a villager in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. She is a 27 year old widow with an 11 year old child currently attending a local school. She owns a small grocery store in the local market.  Since she is a widow and has only one business, she cannot support the family very well. She is asking for a loan to buy a cow to breed in hopes of increasing her income after she sells her cow.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Minh

texts.vi: Chị Minh tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2001. Vòng vốn đầu tiên chị sử dụng để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Hiện nay ngoài trồng trọt và chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn có thêm nghề đánh bắt và buôn bán cá. Công việc chăn nuôi và buôn bán cá của gia đình chị đang phát triển rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 12.000.000đ để đầu tư mua bộ lưới mới phục vụ cho việc đánh bắt cá của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Minh joined TYM fund in 2001. Her first loan was used to invest in raising pigs. Presently, in addition to farming and raising pigs, her family also has a fishing business. Her farming and fishing business are expanding and bring in average income of 180 USD per month. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 725 USD to buy new fishing nets for their fishing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy nets for fishing business

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero O. is 50 years old and married with 5 children. She sells yams at wholesale and retail. She travels to Zakibia, a village in Benue State in Nigeria, which is about 9 hours drive from Benin City each week to purchase yams. Yams are very cheap in Zakibia village. She brings the yams to sell at the yam market in Benin City. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more yams to sell to her customers. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Subhija

texts.en:
Subhija was born in 1959 and she is from Klokotnica. She is married and has two children.  Her son is in high school and her daughter is married and living outside the home.  Subhija has a cow and a field in which she grows vegetables to generate additional income for her family.

Subhija is requesting a loan of 1,000KM ($650 USD) from Women for Women International, which she will use to purchase two calves.  She hopes to raise these calves into adulthood and then sell them at a profit so that she is able to purchase even more calves.  By developing her business, she hopes to generate more income and provide a better life for her family.  This loan will be guaranteed by Sadeta Džebić.

loans.use: To purchase two calves

loans.name: Chhaim

texts.en: 59-year-old Mr. Chhaim C. lives in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. He has two children: one is working in a garment factory and the other is a manager of the family businesses. Mr. C. is a farmer who owns and cultivates rice on a small plot of land, while his wife, Mrs. Yin Toem, is a pig breeder. Since Mrs. Toem's business is going well, she wants to expand it. Her husband is asking for a loan to buy four more piglets and pig food to feed to her pigs. His wife is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy four more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Uoc

texts.vi:
Chị Ước năm nay 41 tuổi, gia đình chị hiện có 2 con đang tuổi đến trường. Năm 1996 chị tham  gia vào Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Từ năm 2000 đến nay ngoài chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn đầu tư thêm vốn để buôn bán rau quả từ hà Nội về bán cho bà con địa phương. Hiện tại đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị. Với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ  cuộc sống của gia đình chị đang  ngày càng được cải thiện hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc buôn bán rau quả của gia đình
texts.en:
Ms. Uoc is 41 years old and has 2 children of school age. In 1996 she joined TYM fund to borrow money to raise pigs. From 2000 until now, in addition to raising pigs she also invested in buying fruits/vegetables from Ha Noi and resell to the local community. These are the main sources of income for her family. With average income of 180 USD, her family's life is improving every day. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 600 USD to invest in her fruits & vegetables business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Adjino

texts.fr:
Née en 1954 à Alédjo au nord du Togo, madame B. Adjino est une femme mariée et a trois (3) enfants qui vont tous à l’école. Elle a pour activité la vente de bois de chauffe et de pagne dans le quartier Agoè au nord de la ville de Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 1998 et vend en gros et en détail. 
Elle est un entrepreneur fidèle de WAGES et rembourse bien ses crédits.
Ce quatrième crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de se préparer pour bien vendre pendant les périodes de fête de fin d’année ; ainsi elle achètera 12 pièces de pagne et 3 tas de bois de chauffe.
texts.en:
Born in 1954 in Alédjo in the north of Togo, Madame Adjino B. is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. As a business activity she sells firewood and pagne (decorated cotton fabric used to make traditional tunics) in the Agoè district north of the town of Lomé. She started this business in 1998 and sells both wholesale and retail. As an entrepreneur she is loyal to Kiva Field Partner, WAGES, and repays her loans satisfactorily. This fourth loan that she is requesting will allow her to make preparations to handle sales during the New Year holiday period. She will thus purchase 12 lengths of pagne and three bundles of firewood.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood and pagne

loans.name: Mouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Mouv S. is a villager in Srae Vong Village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Lach Phan, are farmers who own and cultivate rice on a small field to earn a living. On their plantation, they now face a small problem because infertile soil is badly affecting their crop. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Mouv S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to help her crops grow. 

Mrs. Mouv S. is 46 years old and the mother of six children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory, two assist their parents on the plantation, and three are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase clothing to retail during the Christmas period

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Tuất năm nay 61 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999. Gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh nước giải khát còn các con mở xưởng cơ khí sản xuất và kinh doanh tại nhà. Hàng tháng ngoài nguồn thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng gia đình chị còn có thêm khoản thu 5.000.000đ từ kinh doanh và sản xuất nên kinh tế gia đình rất ổn định và phát triển.
 Vòng vốn tới gia chị xin vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyễn Thị Tuất is 61 years old. She is a TYM fund member since 1999. She has 3 children , all grown up. She runs a refreshment stand and her children a workshop right in their house. Their family income is about 5.000.000 VND a month plus her husband's pension so they are relatively well financially. This time she is requesting a loan of 15.000.000 VND to inject in their family's businesses.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Khursheeda M.din Group

texts.en:
Khursheeda baji is 59 years old and is a wife of M. and resides in a city named Shah Rukn, Pakistan. They have four children: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son is a daily wage labor. Her younger son is a tailor. Her daughters help her embroider clothes for sale, something she has done for 20 years. Her husband has a power loom machine and manufactures bed sheets. Khursheed baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another sewing machine for her younger son so that he able to hire an employee on monthly wage and takes more orders and earn improve his income.

She is joined in her loan group by a the following members. Syeda Nasreen baji requests a loan to buy tools for her carving business. Shazia baji requests a loan to buy vegetables for her vegetable selling business. Nagina baji requests a loan to buy tools for her furniture making business. Najma baji requests a loan to buy material (spices) for her Punjabi food “Dahi Bhalay” selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Šemsudina

texts.en:
Šemsudina was born in 1968 and lives in Zenica, a village in Bosnia. She is married and her husband works in construction outside of Bosnia. She works at home raising an 18 year old daughter and a 13 year old son. 

Šemsudina does embroidery work and sells the finished products to her family and friends. She is requesting a loan of 300KM ($200) from Women for Women International that she will use to buy embroidery materials. She hopes that the supplemental income from selling more embroidery work will improve the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: To buy material for embroidery work.

loans.name: Hodalo

texts.fr:
Madame T. Hodalo est née le 31 décembre 1968 à Tchébébé dans la préfecture de Sotouboua au Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle a pour activité la vente du charbon de bois dans le quartier d’Agoè. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis son enfance et a pris goût après qu’elle soit mariée. Expérimentée dans le domaine, elle connaît tous les risques de son métier.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de refaire son stock avec 30 sacs de charbon de bois.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hodalo T. was born on December 31, 1968 in Tchébébé, in the Sotouboua prefecture in Togo. She's married and the mother of two children. Her business consists in selling charcoal in the Agoè neighborhood. She started this activity during her childhood, and has acquired a taste for it after getting married. Experienced in this field, she knows all the risks involved by her profession. This first loan she's seeking will enable her to resupply her stock with 30 sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 30 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Sokhoeun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun P. is the leader of a five member loan group from Choes Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. Sokhoeun P. owns and cultivates rice on a small piece of land. On her plantation, she now faces the problem of infertile soil, therefore she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to help her crops. Her husband, Mr. Choy Saro, is a cow breeder. Mrs. Sokhoeun P. has two children who are all attending the local school. 

This group loan has end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Agness F.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Agness F. N. from Mbeya. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 10 and 20. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are street children.

Agness has been running a milk business since 1998. Her business is selling milk from her cows to individual consumers. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Agness currently earns about $60 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy more cows so that she can get more profit by selling more milk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Agness thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy more cows so that she can get more profit by selling more milk

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael I. has a business selling plastics. The sales of plastic items such as buckets, laundry baskets, plates, bowls and containers for carrying things is a lucrative business for Rachael. She is 29 years old and single.

She is happy with her business because she has been able to attract customers. She is requesting a loan N120,000 so she can purchase more plastics to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics to sell

loans.name: Sabinus

texts.en:
Sabinus N. is 38 years old. He is married and he has one child. His child is in grade 5 of private school. Sabinus is determined to lift his family above poverty.

He sells sunglasses of various types. He is happy because the festive season is approaching and the demands for his sunglasses will increase.

He is requesting a loan of N50,000 so he can purchase more sunglasses to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sunglasses to sell

loans.name: Fati

texts.fr:
Madame O. Fati est une revendeuse de pagne et de bijoux dans le quartier Agoè. Elle est née en 1962 et s’est mariée à un transitaire qui travaille au port autonome de Lomé. Elle a trois (3) enfants qui fréquentent. Elle aide beaucoup son mari dans les dépenses de la famille. 
Elle est une cliente fidèle de WAGES et a bien remboursé les deux précédents crédits qu’elle a obtenus.
Ce troisième crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de d’acheter 30 pièces de pagnes et 40 complets de bijoux afin de pouvoir bien servir ses clients au cours de ces périodes de fête.
texts.en:
Ms. Fati O. is a retailer of pagnes (coloful West African cloth) and jewelry in the Agoè district. She was born in 1962 and is married to a shipping agent who works at the autonomous port of Lomé. Fati has three children who attend school. She assists her husband a lot with covering family expenses.

She is a loyal client of WAGES and has repaid the two preceding loans that she had obtained. This third loan she is requesting will enable her to buy 30 lengths of pagnes cloth and 40 sets of jewelry in order to serve her customers well during this holiday period.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in pagnes and jewelry

loans.name: Abbass

texts.en: Abbass is a 22 year old man. He lives with his parents in Bourj El Barajneh in the southern suburbs of Lebanon. He is an auto repairer. He asked for a loan of 1000 US dollars in order to pay his wedding expenses. This is the first time that he has requested a loan form Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Abbass needs the loan to pay his wedding expenses

loans.name: Grace G.

texts.en:
Grace is married with two children aged 3 and 9 and lives in Mbeya, Tanzania. Grace runs a business extracting oil from sunflower seeds then selling the oil. The business has been running since 2005. Together with her husband, Grace works six days a week for 9-12 hours a day. Grace currently earns about 50USD from her business. Grace wants to expand her business and extract larger volumes. She is requesting a loan of 425 USD. Grace really appreciates the support she is being given.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To extract more oil in bulk

loans.name: Adakpo Clément

texts.fr:
Monsieur G. Adakpo Clément est né le 31 décembre 1968 à Tsévié ville située à 35 Km de la ville de Lomé. Il est marié et père de deux (2) enfants.  Il a pour activité le commerce de sel en gros dans le marché d’Agoè et au grand marché de Lomé. Généralement ces genres d’activités sont exercés par les femmes mais monsieur G. Adakpo Clément a un goût car c’est une passion pour lui de travailler avec les femmes.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’aller faire l’approvisionnement au Ghana avec 100 sacs de sel afin de pouvoir bien servir ses clients et tirer de bon revenu.
texts.en:
Monsieur Adakpo Clément G. was born on December 31, 1968, in Tsévié - a town in Togo 35 Km from Lomé. He is a married father with two children. For a business activity he sells salt wholesale at the Agoè market and at the big market in Lomé. These types of business activities are normally conducted by women, but Monsieur G. likes it because he loves working with women. This first loan that he is requesting will allow him to stock up in Ghana with 100 sacks of salt to sell to his customers and earn a good income.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of salt

loans.name: Rafiqan M.iqbal Group

texts.en:
Rafiqan baji is a 53-year-old widow who lives in Shah Rukn, Pakistan. She is the mother of six children: three sons and three daughters. Since her husband died from a heart attack, Rafiqan baji has struggled to give her children a good future. She started sewing clothes for people in her neighborhood which grew to sewing clothes for people in her community. She didn’t marry again because she didn’t want to diversify her responsibilities. Her sons are fruit sellers. They buy fruits from a fruit market to sell on fruit carts in different areas in Shah Rukn. Her eldest daughter helps her in stitching clothes. The two younger daughters are in school. Rafigan successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to expand her sons' fruit-selling business. 

She is joined in her loan group by a three members: Zubaida baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shabana baji requests a loan to buy clothes for her cloth-selling business. Firdous baji requests a loan to buy material (colored thread and sketches) for her embroidery business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more seasonal fruits to resell

loans.name: Massalo

texts.fr:
Née le 12 mars 1968 à Aného dans la préfecture des Lacs, madame A. Massalo est une femme vaillante qui exerce le commerce de pagne à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants.  Depuis qu’elle a commencé cette activité elle arrive a aider son mari qui est un Mécanicien auto.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé et vend de quartier en quartier ce qui lui permet de bien vendre car elle s’approche elle-même des clients.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 30 pièces de pagne de variétés différentes.
texts.en:
Born on 12 March 1968 in Aného in the Prefecture of les Lacs, Mrs. Massalo A. is a courageous woman who runs a business selling pagne cloth (a type of brightly printed, valued West African cloth) in Lomé. She is married and has two (2) children. Since she began this business, she has been able to help her husband, who is an auto mechanic. She supplies herself at the grand market in Lomé and sells her goods from district to district, which allows her to sell well, since she has direct contact with her customers. This first loan she is asking for will allow her to buy 30 pieces of pagne cloth of different varieties.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell pagne cloth

loans.name: Tessy

texts.en:
Tessy O. has a shop where she sells pepper soup and drinks. She loves this business because her customers pay cash when they come in to her shop. Ever since she began this business, her desire has been to increase her sales. She is now requesting a loan of N100,000 so she can purchase more pepper soup ingredients and drinks.

Tessy is 40 years old. She is married and she has four children.

She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pepper soup ingredients and drinks to sell

loans.name: Reim

texts.en: Mrs. Reim I., 38 years old, is a villager in Trapaing Chrey Village in Takeo Province. She has a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Moung Vong, is a construction worker who earns a small income to support the family. Although Mrs. Reim I. and her husband work in different businesses, they still cannot support the family well. Therefore, Mrs. Reim I. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. She is the mother of three children: one is employed in a garment factory; another is a construction worker; and, the youngest one is attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie O. is 45 years old. She is married and she has 6 children.

Julie is a hair stylist. She owns a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. As the festive season is approaching, she desires to stock her shop with hair extensions to sell and also to weave in her customers’ hair.

She is requesting a loan of N100,000 so she can purchase one hair dryer and hair extensions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase one hair dryer and more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Agness B.

texts.en:
Agness N. is 41 and lives in Mbeya, Tanzania, with her three children aged between 11 and 19. Agness purchases crops from surrounding villages and then sells them in her retail bases. She works very hard with her elder sister between 9-12 hours a day, 7 days a week.

Agness currently earns about 190USD from her business. With the 425 USD loan, she wants to purchase crops in bulk. In the future she wants to expand her business. She thanks Kiva for the support she has received.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more crops in bulk

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Madame M. Afi est née le 15 février 1965 à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq (5) enfants. Elle a pour activité la vente du maïs et du charbon de bois, commerce qu’elle a commencé depuis l’année 2002. 
Il n’a jamais bénéficié d’un crédit et sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 10 sacs de maïs et 12 sacs de charbon de bois. Avec ce crédit elle pourra bien vendre et aider son mari dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Ms. Afi M. was born on February 15, 1965 in Lomé. She is married and the mother of five. Her work involves selling corn and charcoal, a business that she started in 2002. She has never been the recipient of a loan and is requeseting this initial loan to buy 10 sacks of corn and 12 sacks of charcoal. She will then be able to do well in her sales and to assist her husband with covering family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and charcoal

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en: Kamal is a 43 year old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh in southern suburbs of Lebanon. He owns a small grocery store. He requested a loan of $1000 to buy goods and to decorate its display window. It is his first time that he asked for a loan.

loans.use: Kamal wants the loan to purchase goods and decorate his display window

loans.name: Kamila

texts.en: Kamila was born in 1960 and lives in the Absheron region of Azerbaijan. She is married and has two children. Thirteen years ago she started a business selling groceries and household goods. She is applying for a $1,200 loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Assad

texts.en:
Assad is a 43-year-old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Bourj El Barajneh in southern suburbs of Lebanon. 

Assad owns a taxi. His taxi needs maintenance. Therefore, he has asked for a loan of $1000 (USD) from Al Majmoua. Assad has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua from 4 years and his reputation is very good.

loans.use: Assad wants to do maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Jonesia M.

texts.en:
Jonesia N. is married with two children aged 2 and 8 and lives in Mbeya, Tanzania. Jonesia sells vitenges and kangas, pieces of colorful cloth similar to a sarong. The business has been operating since 2003. Josenia buys the vitenges wholesale and then sells them in her retail outlet. She works 6 days a week for 9-12 hours per day with her husband. Jonesia currently earns about 80USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 500USD to buy larger volumes to obtain bulk volume discounts. In the future, Jonesia hopes to start another business in order to diversify. Jonesia thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase vitenge and kanga in bulk

loans.name: Rabi

texts.fr:
Née en 1979 à Atakpamé, ville située à 180 Km de la capitale du Togo, madame K. Rabi est mariée et mère de deux enfants. En 2001 elle a ouvert son atelier de coiffure dans le quartier Agoè au nord de Lomé. Dans son atelier, elle vend aussi des bijoux et des mèches. 
Son premier crédit lui a permis de d’aménager son atelier afin de pouvoir attirer des clients.
Elle sollicite ce second crédit pour acheter 60 colliers et 45 mèches. Ce nouveau stock lui permettra de pouvoir bien vendre durant la période des fêtes en décembre.
texts.en:
Born in 1979 in Atakpamé, a city 180 km from the capital of Togo, Mrs. Rabi K. is married and has two children. In 2001, she opened a hairdressing studio in the Agoè district in northern Lomé. In her studio, she also sells jewelry and hair extensions. Her first loan allowed her to outfit her studio in order to attract more customers. She is asking for this second loan to buy 60 necklaces and 45 sets of hair extensions. This new stock will allow her to sell well during the period of festivals in December.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry and hair extensions for resale

loans.name: Ekah

texts.en:
Ekah A. has a business selling fuel. Purchasing kerosene and cooking gases is very expensive, so many people resort to using firewood for cooking. Ekah sells firewood and palm oil to those people. She makes the most in sales from her firewood business.

She is now requesting a loan of N120,000 so she can purchase more firewood to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Lucia R.

texts.en:
Lucia K. is 45, married with five children aged between 14 and 22, and lives in Mbeya, Tanzania.

Since 2004, Lucia has been in business buying maize, mallet and sunflower seeds from farmers and selling them in towns. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by her husband. Lucia currently earns about 160USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 425USD in order to purchase additional stock of sunflower seeds, mallet and maize. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Lucia thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of sunflower seeds, mallet and maize.

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chanthorn N. is a villager in Trapeang Sragei village in Takeo Province. She is a grocer. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy grocery goods to re-sell to her customers. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Man Chantha, uses electricity to charge batteries for income. Mrs. Chanthorn N. is 41 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods to re-sell to her customers.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace E. sells clothes. As Chrismas and New Year approach, demands for her clothes will be high and this makes her happy. She hopes to stock her shop with all that her customers need. She is requesting the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible

loans.use: To purchase clothes for the Christmas sales

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 42-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. He is an auto repairer. He has requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua to buy new merchandise for his garage. It is his first time that he asked for a loan.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his garage

loans.name: Aïcha

texts.fr:
Préparant les fêtes de fin d’année, madame E. Aïcha, née le 13 janvier 1969 à Lomé est une revendeuse des produits de consommation courante à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle a ouvert un magasin général dans lequel elle vend du riz, de l’huile, des boites de conserve du sucre etc. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé afin de satisfaire les clients locaux. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis l’année 2000 et maîtrise les contours de ce métier.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 4 sacs de riz, 6 bidons d’huile et 25 sacs sucre en poudre.
texts.en:
Preparations are in the works for the year-end holidays. Ms. Aïcha E., born on January 13, 1969 in Lomé, is a retailer of common consumables in Lomé. She is married and the mother of two children. She has opened a general store in which she sells rice, vegetable oil, canned food, sugar, etc. She gets her supplies at the grand marketplace of Lomé to satisfy her local customers. She started this business in 2000 and is a master of the ins-and-outs of the trade. This initial loan she is requesting will enable her to buy 4 sacks of rice, 6 drums of oil, and 25 sacks of granulated sugar.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food items

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Thoeun T., 28, is married and lives with her three children and husband in Battambong in Cambodia. From her home she has a business selling a variety of stuff such as eggs, tea, vegetable oil, laundry soap and other basic stuff to the people in the village to earn a living and is able to make about US$3.50 of profit each day. Her husband is a construction worker building houses. He earns approximately US$3 per day to help support the family’s expenses. Three of their children are students. She said on average she spends around US$50 on food each month and US$30 on children’s education. 

Thoeun T. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to add to her grocery’s inventory and the rest of the loan will be used to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.use: Add groceries and purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Monsieur A. Kodzo est né le 31 décembre 1983 à à Glévé dans la préfecture de Vo. Il est marié et père de deux (2) enfants. Il est électricien auto et a ouvert son atelier en 2007 dans le quartier d’Agoè.
Souvent il a des difficultés pour servir ses clients dans l’immédiat car il n’a pas tous les outils nécessaires de  travaille.
Il sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter un chargeur de batterie, un fil conducteur et une bobine d’allumage afin de pouvoir mieux servir ses clients et gagner de revenu en retour.
texts.en:
Mr. Kodzo A., born on December 31, 1983 in Glévé (in Vo prefecture) is a married father of two. He is an automobile electrician who opened his own workshop in 2007 in the Agoè district. He often has trouble serving his customers right away because he does not have all the necessary work tools. He is requesting this initial loan to buy a battery charger, an electrical cable, and an ignition coil in order to serve his customers better and to earn more income in return.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy work tools

loans.name: Carol

texts.en: Carol O. is 30 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells provisions like detergents, toothpastes, brushes, etc. She also sells foodstuffs like melon seed, soup spices, yams, garri, etc. She hopes to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs in large quantities to sell to her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Djabo Tezi

texts.fr:
Agée de 50 ans madame A. Djabo Tezi est une mère de famille de quatre (4) enfants. Elle a pour activité, la vente des chaussures et produits de consommation courante. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 1998 et s’approvisionne dans le marché d’Agoè. 
Actuellement son stock des produits d’alimentation général est presque épuisé et elle désire renouveler le stock par l’achat de 3 sacs de riz, 4 cartons de sucre, deux (2) bidons d’huile et deux (2) cartons de spaghetti.
texts.en:
Ms. Djabo Tezi A. is 50 years old and the mother of a family of four. Her work involves selling shoes and common consumables. She started this business in 1998 and gets her supplies from the Agoè marketplace. Currently, her stock of grocery items is almost exhausted, and she would like to renew the stock by buying 3 sacks of rice, 4 boxes of sugar, 2 drums of oil, and 2 boxes of spaghetti.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Aem

texts.en:
Mrs. Aem Y. is a villager in Takap village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Ven Muny, is a construction worker. Even though they have both businesses, they do not have enough money to improve their living conditions. 

Thus, Mrs. Aem Y. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living condition with this loan. 

She is 36 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom attend the local school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy  a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 28-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh in southern suburbs of Lebanon. He owns a small accessory shop and he wants to expand and buy new accessories for his shop. Therefore, he has requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua. This is his first loan.

loans.use: To expand his shop and purchase new accessories

loans.name: Fatuma Y.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Fatuma W. from Mbeya, divorced with four children between the ages of 8 and 16. She has been making and selling clothes since 1998. Working at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Fatuma currently earns about $150 monthly.

She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy in bulk the tailoring materials needed to make more clothes. In the future, she plans to have a shop from which to sell the clothes. Fatuma thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy in bulk tailoring materials to make more clothes.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun M., 35, is married and resides with her two young school-aged children and husband in Battambong in Cambodia. Since 2006, she has been selling roast beef and boiled duck eggs to earn a living and is able to make around US$5 each day. Every day she always prepares stuff and then walks her trailer from house to house to sell beef and duck eggs. Her husband is a construction worker building houses and makes US$3.50 per day. She said on average she spends around US$40 on food each month, US$10 on utilities and US$30 on children’s education.

Chhun M. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work, and sometimes he can take this bike to operate a motor-taxi whenever he is free from construction.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Helen Amen

texts.en:
Helen Amen O. is 42 years old. She is married and she has one child who is in school.

Helen lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has a business selling wood. She goes to the sawmill to purchase logs of wood and to pay so she can saw the wood into different sizes. She then supplies the wood directly to builders for building houses. She is happy because she makes a lot of profit from this business.

Helen is now requesting a loan of N100,000 so she can purchase more wood to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more wood to sell

loans.name: Messanh

texts.fr:
Agé de 27 ans monsieur N. Messanh est un jeune homme dynamique passionné par le commerce. En 2007, il commencé le commerce de friperie dans le marché de Hédzranawoé, l’un des marchés les plus animés de la capitale.
Son stock est composé des chemises pour homme, des chaussures et des pantalons.
Il sollicite ce premier crédit pour augmenter son stock afin de pouvoir bien vendre durant la période des fêtes de fin d’année.
texts.en:
At 27 years of age, Mr. Messanh N. is a dynamic young man who is passionate about business. In 2007, he started a second-hand clothing store in the market at Hédzranawoé, one of the most animated markets in the capital. His stock is composed of men's shirts, shoes, and pants. He is asking for this first loan to increase his stock, so that he will be able to sell well during the festival season at the end of the year.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Korn

texts.en: Mr. Korn S. is a villager in Plouv Trey Village in Kandal Province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate vegetables to earn his living. In his plantation, he faces some problems because his field has infertile soil which affects his crop badly, and he does not have vegetable seeds to support his field. In order to deal with these problems, he decided to ask for a loan to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizers to support his field to make his crop more productive. His wife, Mrs. Chan Yoen, is a cake seller. Mr. Korn S. is 57 years old and the father of three children, two of whom are farmers who help him while the youngest one is attending the local school. His wife is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds and fertilizers to support his field to make his crop more productive.

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El L., 35, is married and resides with her four children and husband in Battambong, Cambodia. She and her husband together work making and selling brooms. This have been in this business for about four years, and normally this couple and the eldest son work making brooms and distribute to the small dealers in the market to sell. On average, this family can make about US$3 of profit each day.

El L. is asking for a loan of US$200 to purchase some materials help to make more brooms. (The eldest son is pictured above.)

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet M. is 52 years old and married with 6 children. Four of her children are currently learning some skills while the other 2 children are planning to further their education but are a little restricted because of lack of funds.

Violet and her husband are farmers. They practice shifting cultivation in farming. They farm in an area called waterside. Violet and her husband cultivate different kind of farm produce like pumpkins, corn, watercress, peppers and tomatoes. When the heat from the sun is too high, they seek shelter inside the little hut they built for resting. Behind her in the picture is the hut and beside her in the picture is her husband.

She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more pumpkin seeds to plant and also to hire laborers for clearing the farm land. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more pumpkin seeds to plant

loans.name: Nikupokigwa M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Nikupokigwa K. from Mbeya, widowed with two children between the ages of 7 and 10. Nikupokigwa has been running a local restaurant business known as “mama lishe” since 2005. This involves buying items such as rice, maize flour, salt, beans etc, and making food to sell to the people around the area. Working at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week and assisted by her mother, Nikupokigwa currently earns about a $50 weekly profit.

She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to purchase more items in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Nikupokigwa thanks you for your support!

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase more items in bulk.

loans.name: Sophors

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophors C. is 24 years old and lives in Ptasrong Commune in Pursat Province. She has two kids; one lives at home, and other one is in school.

Sophors is farmer who has worked her rice crop with her husband, Mr. Vuthy Pen, 25, for income for her family. Sophors is applying a loan of 800,000 riel ($200) to purchase home products and goods to sell by transporting to customer’s houses.

(Sophors and her husband are pictured)

loans.use: to purchase home products and goods

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en: Lorn V., 42, is a widowed grocery seller who lives with her two children. Living in the Battambong province, she typically makes about US$2.50 each day, and her two children who work farming make about US$2.50 each day as well to help support the family. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. Lorn V. would like a loan of US$1000 to add grocery inventory, and the rest of the money is used to repair the house.

loans.use: To add grocery inventory and repair the house.

loans.name: Heak

texts.en: Mrs. Heak D. is a villager in Prey Takap village in Takeo Province. She is a traditional medicine seller. Her husband, Mr. Kun Rath, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn his living. Even though they have different businesses, they still cannot support their family. Thus, Mrs. Heak D. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve her living conditions with this loan. She is 29 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is four years old. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding.

loans.name: Akoura Denise

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants, dame BILANKINAM Akoura Denise est née le 15 mai 1972 à Lomé. Elle a pour activité la préparation et la commercialisation de boisson locale préparée à base du mil et de l’eau. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 1995 et accueille beaucoup de clients surtout dans les week-ends et jours fériés. Son activité nécessite le bois de chauffe et du mil ce qui lui pousse à solliciter ce premier crédit pour acheter 4 sacs de mil et 5 fagots de bois.
texts.en:
Married and a mother with four children, Ms. Akoura Denise BILANKINAM was born on May 15, 1972 in Lomé. Her work involves making and marketing a local beverage prepared with millet and water. She started this business in 1995 and accommodates many customers, especially on weekends and public holidays. Her work requires firewood and some millet, and this drives her to apply for this initial loan to buy 4 sacks of millet and 5 bundles of firewood.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy millet and firewood for making a local drink

loans.name: Phal

texts.en:
Phal S., 34, is married and lives with her two children and husband in Battambong province, Cambodia. She opened a beauty salon shop and sometimes she is hired to arrange clothes for grooms and brides for their weddings. On average, she makes US$3 each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and he is able to make US$2.50 a day.

Phal S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase more decorative materials.

loans.use: To purchase more decorative materials.

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en: Mrs. Choeun S. is a villager in Trapeang Sragei village in Takeo Province. She is a pig breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand her business so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Chhem Kim, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn his living. Mrs. Choeun S. is 50 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Horm

texts.en:
Horm N., 38, is a widow and lives with her one daughter and her old mother in Battambong province, Cambodia. She and her daughter work making mats to sell at the market. On average, she earns around US$2 each day. Besides making mats, she also grows rice but her output is just enough for her family each year only. 

Horm N. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase materials to make more mats.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 45-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Ali is a carpenter. He has requested a loan of $500 from Al Majmoua to pay the school fees for his three children. This is the first time that he has asked for a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To pay his children's school fees

loans.name: Aem

texts.en:
Mrs. Aem P. is a villager in Prey Takap village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. She faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to support her living. 

Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living with this loan after she sells the cow. 

She is a 68 years old widow and the grandmother of two grandsons who attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Mazalo

texts.fr:
Madame T. Mazalo est née le 13 août 1965 à Adjengré au nord du Togo. Elle est célibataire avec des enfants. Son activité principale est la vente des céréales. C’est une femme qui lutte beaucoup pour la réussite de sa vie. Elle assure aussi la charge de ses petites sœurs avec le peu de revenu qu’elle gagne.
Elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour faire le stock des céréales par l’achat de 200 tubercules d’igname, 3 sacs de mil et 1 sac  de maïs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mazalo T. was born on August 13, 1965 in Adjengré in Northern Togo. She's single with children. Her business mainly consists in selling cereals. She's a woman who works really hard to succeed in life. Out of her meager income, she also provides for her younger sisters. She's seeking this first loan to create a stock of cereals, by purchasing 200 yams, 3 sacks of millet and one sack of corn.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase yams, millet and corn

loans.name: Sovany

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovany S., 37, lives in Kompongtom Commune in Kompong Tom Province. She has three children, two daughters and one son, all of whom are students. Her husband, Mr. Bunthy Peng, is 39 years old and is a policeman.

Sovany sells Kmer Noodle. Her business is mobile so she sells in different areas in her village; she has run her business since 2006. She is now applying for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for easier transportation.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Fahed

texts.en: Fahed is a 42-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Fahed owns a taxi and, because of the age of his car, he wants to buy a new engine for it. Therefore, Fahed has requested a loan of $1000 to remove his old engine and buy a new one. This is the first time that he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase a new engine for his car

loans.name: Thera

texts.en: Mrs. Thera P. is a villager in Trapeang Sragei village in Takeo Province. She is a chicken seller who buys from other people in the local village and sells in the market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand her business so she decided to ask for a loan to buy some chickens for selling. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Toeng Phon, is a car repairer. Mrs. Thera P. is 28 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy some chickens for selling.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch K., 27, is married and lives with two young children and her husband in Battambong province, Cambodia. Since 2000, she and her husband together have been selling grocery items from her home to earn a living and are able to make US$8 in revenue a day. She said she spends US$60 on food each month and US$2 on utilities.

She would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to add more grocery inventory.

loans.use: To add more grocery inventory.

loans.name: Srey Hong

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Hong K. is a villager in Prey Takap village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Ol Eit, is a construction worker who gets a small salary. Even though they have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well. Thus, Mrs. Srey Hong K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase their income and improve her living conditions with this loan after she sells her cow. She is 21 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study because that child is two years old. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy cow for breeding.

loans.name: Melithe N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 53-year-old Melithe M. from Mbeya, married with eight children between the ages of 12 and 34 and also responsible for supporting one dependent whose parents died of HIV. Melithe has been running a vitenge (sarong-like women’s garments) business since 2005, buying them wholesale and then retailing them. Working at the business for five to eight hours per day six days per week and assisted by her husband. Melithe currently earns about $200 each month from her business.

She is now requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy more vitenge and wool in bulk, and in the future plans to expand and add another business. Melithe thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vitenge and wool in bulk.

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mok K. L., 42, is married and lives with her three children and husband in Battambong province, Cambodia. She and her husband together sell many kinds of desserts at the market to earn approximately US$8 each day. She would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for her to transport dessert to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Séna Bénoït

texts.fr:
Monsieur G. Séna Benoît est né le 16 avril 1982 à Sokodé dans la région centrale du Togo. Il est célibataire et a en charge son frère qui va à l’école. Il a pour activité commerciale la vente de vêtements dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Il fait ses achats au port autonome de Lomé.
Cette activité qu’il a commencé depuis 2006 lui rapporte beaucoup de revenus et il arrive à supporter ses charges et celui de son frère.
Il sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter Une balle de chemise et un carton de chaussure afin de pouvoir bien vendre pendant la période des fêtes de fin d’année.
texts.en:
Mr. Séna Benoît G. was born on April 16, 1982 in Sokodé, in Central Togo. He's single and must support his brother who attends school. He's main business consists in selling clothes in the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé. He purchases his goods at Lomé Autonomous Port. This business, which he started in 2006, brings in a lot of income for him, so that he manages to provide for his brother and himself. He's seeking this first loan to buy a bale of shirts and some shoes, to make good sales during the end-of-year holiday season.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy ten piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok C. is a 51-year-old local farmer who started her business over twenty years ago. 

Sok is a mother of nine children; four are married and live away from home, and the other five are students who also help the family’s farm. Her husband, Mr. Chi Eang, 49, makes a living as a palm tree climber, making palm juice and turning it into palm wine to sell. 

Sok is applying for a $900 loan to purchase a trailer to use with her motorcycle to make work easier. They live in Tnotchroum Commune in Pursat Province.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle trailer

loans.name: Yong

texts.en: Yong V., 32, works with her husband together making rice wine and raising pigs on a plot of land near her house. She earns on average about US$4 each day. This couple has two young children. Yong V. would like to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase more pigs, and the rest of the money is used to help in making rice wine.

loans.use: Raise pigs.

loans.name: Mpoki N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 18-year-old Mpoki N. from Tukuyu, a married woman who has been operating a crop-selling business since 2002. Assisted by her husband, she works at the business four hours per day, seven days per week, earning a monthly profit of about $50.

She is now requesting a loan of $500 in order to buy more crops in bulk, and in the future plans to expand and establish another business. Mpoki thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more crops in bulk.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap C. is a villager in Kor Chenleng village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Hong Samboo, are farmers who own a piece of land where they cultivate rice to earn their living. They cannot support their living conditions because their rice revenue is too little. Thus, Mrs. Pheap C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start another business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cow. She is 37 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in garment factory while the other children are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start another business.

loans.name: Chheuk

texts.en: Chheuk P., 30, works raising pigs together with her husband on a plot of land near her house and earns around US$4 each day. This couple has two young children and resides with an old mother in Battambong province, Cambodia. Chuueuk P. would like to take out a loan of US$600 to increase her livestock and purchase feed for pigs as well.

loans.use: Raise pigs.

loans.name: Tum

texts.en: Mrs. Tum K. is a villager in Kor Chenleng village in Takeo Province. She is a hen breeder. Her husband, Mr. Hun Hoem, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice to earn his living. Since Mrs. Tum K.’s business is going well, she wants to expand; unfortunately, she does not have enough money to buy hens and hen food. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizers to support her husband's field to make his crop more productive. She is 32 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy hens and hen food and fertilizers to support her husband field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Happy R.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Happy M. from Mbeya, married with three children between the ages of two and six. Happy has been running a butchery business since 2003 buying cows and selling the meat to consumers. Assisted by her husband, she works at the business five to eight hours per day, six days per week and earns about $150 each month from her business.

She is now requesting a loan of $650 in order to expand her operations. Happy thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Lieng

texts.en: Mrs. Lieng S. is a villager in Peak Bang Aung village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn her living. Her husband, Mr. Mut Kuch, is a construction worker. With their revenue, they cannot improve their living conditions. Thus, Mrs. Lieng S. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding to start a new business. She hopes to increase their income and improve her living conditions after she sells her cows. She is 31 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study because they are five and two years old. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding to start a new business.

loans.name: Pouv

texts.en:
Mr. Pouv C., 45, is a teacher who teaches secondary school and gets a salary for $50 per month. He lives in Ptasrong Commune, Pursat Province, and is married to Mrs. Phon Long, 43. Phon makes a living farming rice. She is the mother of four kids who attend school. 

Pouv is applying for a loan to purchase raw materials to make stoves and to buy nets to resell as another source of income. This income increase will help with supporting the children and their education.

loans.use: to purchase stove-making materials

loans.name: Gulru

texts.ru:
Назарова Гулру Пиримшоевна, 1974 года рождения, замужем и у них 2 детей. Начала свой бизнес с продажи кондитерских изделий. Со временем она перешла в продажу различных тканей. Сейчас в ассортименте ее товаров постельное белье, мужские свитера, женские пуловеры, детские зимние одежды, а также зимние носки. В бизнесе ей помогает дочка. Они вместе торгуют в отдаленных районах. Они возят товар прямо им домой, это куда выгоднее покупателям, чем тратить на дорогу. У нее 8 лет опыта в этой деятельности. Она покупает товар на оптовом рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе. У Гулру есть постоянные клиенты, которые заказывают все новые товары, она постоянно обновляет свой товар, чтоб не потерять постоянных клиентов. 
Гулру хочет получить с помощью программы Кива займ в сумме 1100 сомони чтоб закупить зимние товары.

loans.use: закуп зимних носков

loans.name: Debora A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Debora M. from Mbeya, married with three children between the ages of 5 and 12. Debora has been running a clothes business since 1999, supplying uniforms for primary schools. Working at the business 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and assisted by her husband, she currently earns about $45 per month.

She is now requesting a loan of $425 in order to purchase more clothes in bulk, and in the future plans to expand her business. Debora thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Tavakal

texts.ru: Гафурова Тавакал житель района Шахринау. Замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Основным кормильцем семьи является она и путем бизнеса она обеспечивает своих детей всем необходимым. Но для того , чтобы увеличить товарооборот и прибыльность бизнеса решила обратиться к нам за кредитом. Планируемый кредит использует для ввоза нового товара. Погашать кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Tavakal G. lives in the Shahrinau region. She is married and has six children. Tavakal is the main provider for her large family and with her business she is able to supply her children with everything necessary. However, in order to expand her business and increase profits Tavakal has turned to Kiva for a loan. She wants to use the loan to finance a large wholesale purchase of additional goods. Tavakal is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand inventory and purcahse additianl goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy cow for breeding in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.name: Leap

texts.en:
Mrs. Leap P. is a 58-year-old widow living in Sarikakeo Commune in Kandal Province. She has five children; one is married, one daughter is employed as a garment worker in Phnom Penh City, and another daughter sells fish from village to village to earn extra income to help meet her family's expenses.

Leap is a rice farmer who has been farming since 1975. She is applying for $600 to purchase two oxen to help plow her farm land.

Leap is pictured with her family.

loans.use: to buy two oxen

loans.name: Čaza

texts.en:
Čaza was born in 1969 and she lives in Banovići, a village in Bosnia.  She is married and has two children: an adult son who works as a baker, and a 17 year old daughter who attends high school.  Her husband fought in the Bosnian War in the 1990s and is now disabled. 

Although her husband receives a small disability pension from the government, Čaza is largely the one responsible for supporting her family. She grows vegetables and raises chickens, selling the eggs in the local market. 

Čaza is requesting a loan of 600KM ($400 USD) from Women for Women, International, which she will use to buy more chickens and expand her business.  She hopes that the additional income from the new chickens will help to provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Neema D.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Nema D. S. from Mbeya, married with five children between the ages of 5 and 14. Neema has been running a local restaurant business since 1990. Working at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week and assisted by her husband. Neema currently earns about $200 each month.

She is requesting a loan of $650 in order to purchase more rice, beans, salt, flour and cooking oil in bulk for her restaurant, and in the future plans to expand her business. Neema thanks you for your support!

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, beans, salt, flour and cooking oil in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a new grocery store

loans.name: Mejra

texts.en:
Mejra was born in 1969 and she lives in Šerići, a village in Bosnia. She is married and has 8 children. Her oldest daughter is 17 and her youngest son is 4.
