Her husband earns 800KM/month and they receive 360KM/month in child support from the government, which totals the equivalent of $740 USD/month to support a family of 10.  

Mejra works as a housewife, growing vegetables and raising cows to feed her family.

Mejra is requesting a loan of 1,200KM ($800 USD) from Women for Women International to purchase food for her cows to survive the winter. The loan is important for her, because her cows' milk and milk products are crucial to feeding her family.

loans.use: To buy food for cows

loans.name: Mirzo

texts.ru: Турсунов Мирзо житель района Шахринау. Возраст 48 лет. Женат  и имеет пятерых детей. Уже 10 лет зарабатывает деньги путем бизнеса. Бизнес в животноводстве занимает все его время. Он скупает животных и перепродает на рынках. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы закупить комбикорм. Это даст возможность ей без проблем откармливать бычков. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mirzo T. lives in the Shakhrinau District. He is 48 years old, married, and has five children. For 10 years already he has made his living through business. His animal husbandry business takes up all of his time. He buys animals and resells them at markets. He decided to take out a loan in order to purchase complete feed. This will allow him to finish bull calves with no problem. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of complete feed

loans.name: Reth

texts.en:
Mrs. Reth B., 43, is a rice farmer in Snampras Commune in Pursat Province. Her husband, Mr. Thoeun Choun, 44, has been a construction worker for the past six years. He also works with his wife.

Reth has been farming since early 2007. She has requested a loan to purchase oxen to help with her farm work. This will help her increase her income as well as provide her with a new fixed asset.

loans.use: To purchase oxen

loans.name: Maksida

texts.en:
Maksida was born in 1970 and she lives in a Živinice, a village in Bosnia.  She has 3 kids: her oldest son is 20 and works as a construction worker, and her two other sons are 14 and 12 years old and still attend school.  Her husband also works in construction.  

Maksida works at home, raising her children, growing vegetables, and raising cows.  She sells the milk and milk products from her cows in the local market, earning about 150KM/month (the equivalent of roughly $100 USD).  Maksida requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International to purchase food for her cows to survive the winter.

loans.use: To buy food for cows.

loans.name: Gulru

texts.ru:
Назарова Гулру Пиримшоевна, 1974 года рождения, замужем и у них 2 детей. Начала свой бизнес с продажи кондитерских изделий. Со временем она перешла в продажу различных тканей. Сейчас в ассортименте ее товаров постельное белье, мужские свитера, женские пуловеры, детские зимние одежды, а также зимние носки. В бизнесе ей помогает дочка. Они вместе торгуют в отдаленных районах. Они возят товар прямо им домой, это куда выгоднее покупателям, чем тратить на дорогу. У нее 8 лет опыта в этой деятельности. Она покупает товар на оптовом рынке «Корвон» города Душанбе. У Гулру есть постоянные клиенты, которые заказывают все новые товары, она постоянно обновляет свой товар, чтоб не потерять постоянных клиентов. 
Гулру хочет получить с помощью программы Кива займ в сумме 1100 сомони чтоб закупить зимние товары.
texts.en:
Born in 1974, Gulru N. is married and has two children. She started her business by selling confectionery products and then transitioned into various fabrics sales. Her current goods assortment includes bedding, men’s sweaters, women’s pullovers, children’s winter clothes and winter socks. Gulru’s daughter helps her with the business. They travel together extensively to make sales and deliver products directly to customers’ homes. Gulru has 8 years of experience in this business. She purchases goods at the Korvon wholesale market in Dushanbe. She has repeat clients who order new products from her, thus she has to often update her inventory in order to retain her clients. With the help of the Kiva program, Gulru wants to obtain a $325 loan in order to buy winter goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase winter socks

loans.name: Eliza J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 54-year-old Eliza M. from Mbeya, married with four children between the ages of 10 and 20. Eliza has been running a crop business since 2007, buying rice wholesale and retailing it locally. Working at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, Eliza currently earns about a $60 monthly profit.

She is now requesting a loan of $750 in order to purchase more rice in bulk, and in the future plans to expand her business. Eliza thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Rom

texts.en:
Mrs. Rom C., 49, sells groceries out of her home to neighbors in her village. Her husband, Mr Veasna Tum, 76, is a construction supervisor who always leaves home early in the morning to work to support the family. Together they have five children; three are employed and two are married.

Rom is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband for transportation.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Abdujabor

texts.ru: Алиев Абдуджабор житель района Шахринау. Возраст 22 года. Совсем недавно женился , но живет с женой и с родителями. Семья очень большая. И уже 4 года он работает в лепешечной. Выпекает лепешки для реализации оптом. Дело приносит доход, но в связи с тем , что в зимний период увеличивается спрос на продукцию и  он не успевает закупать муку. Поэтому он решил получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев. Это поможет ему увеличить товарооборот , а так же привлечь новых клиентов. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Abdujabor A. resides in the Shahrihay region. He is 22 years old and, although he married recently, he and his wife live with his parents. Their family is quite large. For the past four years he has worked in a bakery which makes traditional bread, sometimes called naan, Bukharan bread, or lepeshka. He bakes bread for sale wholesale. The business yields a return, but the fact is that the demand increases in the wintertime and he is unable to purchase flour. Therefore he has decided to take out a loan, which will enable him to increase his output as well as attract new customers. He will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: Emsada

texts.en:
Emsada was born in 1978 and she lives in Rostov, a suburb in Bosnia.  She is married and has two children who are 5 and 11 years old.  Her husband has seasonal work, operating a tractor for local farmers.  Between his jobs, Emsada supports her family by growing vegetables and selling milk from her cow.  

Emsada requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International to buy a second cow.  She hopes that the additional income from selling milk and milk products will help to improve the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Agnes M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Agnes N. from Mbeya, married with two children between the ages of 14 and 18. She has been running a shop and poultry business since 2005. Working at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, Agnes currently earns about $462 each month.

She is now requesting a loan of $650 in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil and home supplies, and in the future plans to expand and establish another business. Agnes thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil and home supplies

loans.name: Amela

texts.en:
Amela was born in 1974 and she lives in a Banovići.  She is married and has one daughter who is 8 years old. Her husband works as a coal miner. Amela grows vegetables, raises chickens seasonally, and grows strawberries in the summertime.  

Amela requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women International to purchase chickens and food for the chickens.  She says that she wants to have her own income and be financially independent from her husband.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. Keo S. is 41 years old and sells Kmer Noodle in Bathrotes Village in the Preynhy Commune in Pursat Province. Her husband, Mr. Bunna Doch, 43, is in the Cambodian Military and earns a salary of $50 per month. Together they have five children, all of whom are in school.

Keo is seeking a loan of $100 to buy rice and other ingredients for her business.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients

loans.name: Nafija

texts.en:
Nafija was born in 1958 and she lives in Rostov, a suburb in Bosnia.  She is married and her husband is retired. He receives 200KM/month from his retirement pension, the equivalent of just $128 USD/month. This is not enough income to support the family, so they have several small businesses on the side.  

They grow and sell tomatoes and potatoes, they own two cows and sell the milk to their neighbors, and they manage a small corn field, so that they have corn to feed their cattle. 

Nafija requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International to purchase food for her cattle to survive the winter. The loan is important for her, because her cows are her primary source of income.

loans.use: To purchase food for cattle

loans.name: Tozagul

texts.ru: Калонова Тозагуль проживает в районе Шахринау. Имеет свой бизнес. Имеет столовую на центральном рынке района. Замужем и имеет троих детей. В данный момент помещение в котором она работает необходимо сделать ремонт. Поэтому она обратилась за кредитом со сроком в 12 месяцев. Ремонт в помещение поможет привлечь новых клиентов и соответственно увеличить прибыль.
texts.en:
Tozagul K. lives in the Shahrinau region. She is married and has three children. Tozagul manages her own business - a cafe at the region's central market. Currently the space where her cafe is located is in need of improvement. To finance the construction Tozagul needs to take out this loan for the next 12 months. Improving her cafe will help her attract new clients and increase the profits from her business.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improvement of retail space

loans.name: Sokhoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoun N. is a 29-year-old grocery seller who has been in business since early 2007, selling out of her home and earning around US $4.00 per day. She is the mother of two children, both students who also help her with her business. Sokhoun is married to Mr. Sokaiy Hang, 35, a goldsmith.

Recently Sokhoun has been selling her goods until she is completely out of stock. She is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase more grocery inventory to stock and resell. This will allow her to increase her revenue and meet her family's living expenses.

Sokhoun and her family live in the area of Resey Krok Commune, Banteay Meanchey Province.

loans.use: To purchase grocery inventory

loans.name: Chomrong

texts.en:
Mr. Chomrong M. is 28 years old and works for a stone-crushing factory. He began working there in 2006 and currently earns approximately US $3.00 each day.

Chomrong's wife, Mrs. Noeuk Mao, 28, is a farmer who specializes in growing rice and vegetable crops. She is also a good housewife who care for their two young children, both of whom go to school. Together the family lives in Oprasat Commune, Banteay Meanchey Province. 

Chomrong is requesting a loan of US $250 for his wife, to purchase rice seeds. This loan will help them increase their income so they can support their children's school fees, as well as their daily meals.

Chomrong's wife, Noeuk, is pictured because Chomrong was unavailable at the time.

loans.use: to purchase rice seeds

loans.name: Sarvinoz

texts.ru: Калонова Сарвиноз проживает в районе Шахринай.Не замужем. Живет со своими родителями. Ей 24 года и уже четыре года она имеет свой диллерский центр , где торгует картами. Хочет получить кредит для того, чтобы закупить карты и других провайдеров. Эьто поможет ей увеличить доход , путем привлечения новых клиентов. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sarvinoz K. lives in the Shahrinaw District. She is not married and lives with her parents. She is 24 years old and has her own small business where she has sold phone cards for the past 4 years. She wants a loan in order to stock up on cards and different service providers. The loan will help her increase profits by attracting new clients. She will repay the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase telephone cards

loans.name: Kwadjo Bessan

texts.fr: Né en 1970 à Gapé, Mr A. Kwadjo Bessan est marié et a appris la mécanique, métier qu’il n’exerce pas tellement faute de moyen financiers et de soutien depuis la mort de ses parents. Pour sortir de la misère  Bessan est obligé de se faire engager comme manœuvre dans un centre de réparation et de lavage de véhicules et motos pendant deux ans. Maîtrisant tous les rouages de ce travail et soucieux de son avenir, il envisage de se prendre en charge en créant son propre atelier. L’espace étant déjà trouvé et aménagé, il sollicite ce prêt pour acquérir des matériels  pour démarrer son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kwadjo Bessan A., born in 1970 in Gapé, is a married man. He learned how to be a mechanic, a trade he doesn't practice so much for lack of financial means and support since his parents died. To rise out of poverty, Bessan has been compelled for the last two years to work as a laborer in a center for cleaning and repairing vehicles and motorbikes. Mastering the ins and outs of this work and concerned about his future, he envisions being on his own by establishing his own workshop, which he has already found and fixed up. He is requesting this loan to acquire supplies for starting his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairing and cleaning vehicles

loans.name: Hasrat

texts.en: Hasrat M. lives in the town of Khachmaz in Azerbaijan.  He was born in 1984 and is single. He is in the business of selling tables and chairs. Hasrat has been in this business for three years. He would like to improve this business and requests a loan of 970 AZN to purchase tables and chairs.

loans.use: Purchase tables and chairs

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr: Madame A. Albertine est mariée et mère de 3 enfants résidant à Aného. Ayant perdu son mari, elle est seule à faire face aux besoins de la famille. Elle fait le commerce des bijoux qui ne lui permet plus de faire face aux charges de la famille. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour associer à son ancienne activité la vente de mèche et de produits cosmétiques qui est très rentable afin de pouvoir faire face aux besoins de sa famille et surtout pour la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Albertine A. is married and the mother of three and lives in Aného. Having lost her husband, she is alone in coping with the needs of the family. She does commerce in jewelry that enables her to cope. She is requesting this loan to include in her former work the sale of hair extensions and cosmetics, which are very profitable. She can then address family needs especially schooling the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell cosmetics, hair extensions, and jewelry

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence M. is a member of the Twisakirala group in Jinja.  She is a very hard working lady who has managed to run her retail shop for three years.  She has seen her shop grow, a thing that seemed impossible at the start, with the help of loans.  She has been able to improve the quality and quantity of what she sells from her shop, and as a result, her children go to one of the good schools in her locality with a large percentage of fees paid.  Florence needs a loan to help with buying more products for her shop to make more profits.

loans.use: To stock her retail shop.

loans.name: Paulin

texts.fr: Marié et père de trois enfants, A. Paulin n’à pas continué ses études par manque de moyen financier. Devenu un artiste peintre dessinateur, il a un atelier dans la ville d’Aného où il travaille. Il a pour don la créativité et est reconnu dans la ville pour ses dessins. Dans le souci de professionnaliser son atelier il sollicite ce financement pour faire des achats de matériels pour doubler son chiffre d’affaires et faire plus de bénéfices et assurer ainsi l’éducation et l’avenir de ces enfants.
texts.en:
Married and the father of three children, Paulin A. did not pursue his studies due to a lack of financial means. He became a painter and a drawer, and now has a workshop in Aného, where he draws and paints. He's gifted and very creative, and is well known in the city for his drawings. Anxious to professionalize his workshop, he's seeking this loan to purchase materials to double his revenues and make more profit, in order to ensure the education and the future of his children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for his painting workshop

loans.name: Kyogaya Women's Group

texts.en: Betty N. is the leader of Kyogaya women’s group in Namulesa, Jinja.  She is a single mother with 5 children, and she cares for 3 orphans.  Betty is one of the founding members of her lending group and has tailoring and bar businesses.  With tailoring, she has had the business for over ten years and with the help of the loans, it’s through tailoring that she has been able to start up the bar where she sells local brew and bottled beers in addition to drinks like soda, passion fruit juice, and many others.  She runs both businesses concurrently.  Betty needs a loan to help with buying material and threads for her tailoring business as well as stocking more beers and other drinks for her bar.

loans.use: To buy clothing materials for sewing and drinks for her bar.

loans.name: Homira

texts.en:
Homira she is uneducated and single and lives with her own family. She makes brocade at her home and sells it in bazaar to shopkeepers. She has been involved in this business for more than 10 years since the Taliban regime. She took her first loan to buy some necessary materials and continue her business, but now but she wants to make her business stronger.

So she requested an individual loan of 30000 Afghans for the term of 10 months to buy one or two machines for making brocade to make a better income for her family and a better future for herself.

She is very happy with this loan and she would like to thank lenders around the world. She wants to thank Kiva and AFSG for this successful loan process in Afghanistan she wants to continue her partnership to make life easier in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy one or two sewing machines

loans.name: Adakou Edith

texts.fr: Madame C. Adakou Edith est une femme divorcée et mère de deux enfants qu’elle élève seule. C’est une femme très dynamique malgré le fait qu’elle n’a pas eu la chance de faire des études. Elle s’est lancée dans le commerce en ouvrant une boutique d'alimentation générale. Mais avec son divorce, elle est la seule à faire face aux besoins de ses enfants. Cela a pesé sur son commerce qui ne se développe plus par manque de moyens. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour relancer et développer son commerce en faisant une nouvelle commande d’articles afin de réapprovisionner sa boutique, faire de bénéfice et faire face aux besoins de ces enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Adakou Edith C. is a divorced woman and the mother of two children who she is raising by herself. This is a very energetic woman despite not having had the chance to attend school. She got started in commerce by opening a grocery store. But with her divorce, she is alone, coping with the needs of her children. This weighs upon her business, which is no longer improving due to a lack of funds. She is requesting this loan to reinvigorate and develop her commerce by ordering new merchandise for restocking her store, to make a profit, and to address her children's needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her store with merchandise

loans.name: Mayangayanga Women's Group

texts.en: Betty K. is a proud member of Mayangayanga women’s group in Nakifuma, Kayunga.  She is one of the founding members of the group and runs a retail shop in the town center.  Betty is so impressed with her lending group because she has been able to buy more shop products using her loans, and once the profits come in from the variety, repaying back her loan is no problem.  Betty’s shop is now big and this has made her big profits in return.  She is also grateful to her husband with whom she works in the shop and on their farms for a better life of their family and children.  Betty says that each new loan helps her to buy new missing products for her shop as her profits and savings help to increase the quantity of the already existing products.  Betty needs a loan to help with buying more eggs for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more eggs and other goods for her shop.

loans.name: Ayélé

texts.fr: Retraité de l’enseignement, Mme G. Ayélé  est mariée et mère de sept (07) enfants. Seule à faire face aux charges de la famille avec une pension de retraite qui n’est pas au rendez-vous à la fin de chaque mois, elle n’a que sa boutique d’alimentation générale qui lui procure juste de quoi survivre avec  la famille. Elle a vraiment besoin de financement pour développer son activité et augmenter son revenu afin de supporter sans problème les nombreux besoins de la famille et surtout l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Retired from teaching, Mrs Ayele G. is married and the mother of seven (7) children. Alone to meet the family expenses, her retirement pension is not enough to get through to the end of the month. She has only her general food shop to earn just enough to meet the family needs. She requires financing to develop her business activities and increase her revenues to meet, without difficulty, the many requirements of her family, particularly the education of her children.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase provisions for her general store

loans.name: Habib

texts.en:
Habib is a 60-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. 

Habib owns a grocery shop where he sells vegetables and candy. He has requested a loan of $1100 from Al Majmoua in order to improve his assets. Habib has been a micro-credit client for a long time and has always repaid his loans on time.

Habib has owned his grocery shop for 39 years. He is open every day of the week until late at night. Habib has a good reputation in his village, thanks to the quality of merchandise he offers. His clients are his home and shop neighbors and as well as people who walk by. 

He is willing to purchase more merchandise to improve his business and satisfy more his clients’ needs. Habib has been having difficulty getting reimbursement from former clients. In small villages, asking for reimbursement might sound rude, especially when your best clients are neighbors and family.  

Before the repetitive Lebanese wars, Habib used to own 12 shops. Habib has lost a lot and, adding to it, there has been much theft. Indeed, all this has affected a lot his business. 
 
All through the situation, Habib has remained a tough man and he is planning, in the future, to open a mini market, rather than another grocery shop, because he wants to expand his business and diversify his merchandise.

loans.use: Habib needs the loan to improve his business

loans.name: Berdimurot

texts.en:
G. Berdimurot is 51 years old.  He is a working man used to working the harvest from dusk to sundown. He lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan.  His wife  is also very hard-working.  G. and his wive have two children and harvest four plots of land. They grow wheat, onions, and potatoes in their fields. Their work supports the family. The photograph depicts his wife and daughter working the land.

They are requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to purchase more seeds and mineral fertilizer to grow more vergetables.  The crops need to be maintained to ensure that they will be high-quality for the harvest.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Onorhon

texts.ru: Туйчиева Анорхол разведенная женщина. Возраст 38 лет. Имеет троих детей. Имеет торговую точку на рынке"Саховат" города ДУшанбе. Для развития бизнеса планирует увеличить товарооборот, путем получения кредита. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Onorhon T. is divorced. She is 38 years old and has three children. She has a shop in the Sakhovat market in Dushanbe. In order to develop her business, she plans to increase sales by taking out a loan. She plans to pay off the loan in twelve months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
H. Munavvar is from an agricultural family. She has observed that growing good vegetables requires intense labor and dedication.  With this work ethic, she cultivates produce native to the region such as potatoes and corn. She is a mother of two small children.  Not long ago, she decided to supplement her income by raising small animals. These animals are allowed to roam and find their sustenance while she cultivates the land. Her husband and mother-in-law help her in her work. 

Currently, Munavvar seeks a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to invest in seeds and mineral fertilizer to improve the quality of her produce.  She is also planning to grow potatoes and onions.

loans.use: to rurchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mukisa Women's Group

texts.en: Fatumah B. is one of the executive members of Mukisa women’s group in Jinja as well as one of its founding members.  Fatumah is a tailor with a business of making ladies’ wear, childen's and men’s clothes of all kinds. She has been in the trade for a long time now and has gained experience for making quality products for her customers. She has two sewing machines at the moment, but has a dream of one day owning as many as ten so that she can begin a tailoring school to teach young girls, mostly orphans, the same trade as a way for them to sustain themselves in future.  She is grateful for the loans because now she is able to sell some of the material she buys to her customers, unlike before when she did not have the capital to do so.

loans.use: To buy clothing material and threads for her business.

loans.name: Abdugafar

texts.en: K. Abdugafar is married, has 4 children, and is a farmer. Not fortunate enough to attend school, he very early on embraced working in the fields. Due to this work, he is somehow meeting the needs of his family. His wife also helps to support their household working with her husband. Today, exhausted from crude farming methods, Abdugafar brings in less and less income, which has a negative impact on his household. He is requesting a loan of 3500 Somoni for the term of 12 months in order to buy seeds and fertilizer to augment his crop yields. All of this will then allow him to increase his income and improve his family’s standard of living, especially his dear children for the sake of whom he is working hard. Abdugafar and his family are sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Twejjeko Women's Group

texts.en: Damalie B. is the leader of Twejjeko women’s group in Jinja.  She is married with four children, and she cares for one child belonging to her young sister.  Damalie has a beauty salon in Jinja that has been in existence for five years. When she had just started with the salon, she had only a few customers and each would bring with her the chemicals and braids to be used on her head, but now she is able to stock braids, weaves, and hair chemicals from which customers pick.  The four years she has been with her lending group are non-regrettable because she has also been able to buy a plot of land as well as building her family's house with her husband.

loans.use: To buy braids, weaves and chemicals for her salon.

loans.name: Sénadé

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de sept enfants, Mme K. Sénadé vit avec son mari instituteur à Afagnan. Afin de contribuer aux nombreuses charges de la famille et aider son mari, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce des noix de palmistes qu’elle achète aux paysans et qu’elle revend aux industries productrices d’huiles végétales. Pour améliorer cette activité et avoir une part considérable de ce marché prometteur dans la région, elle sollicite  un financement pour augmenter la quantité de noix de palme à offrir à ses clients. Cela lui assurera un revenu considérable qui lui permettra de faire face aux besoins d’éducation de ses enfants sans soucis majeurs.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of seven children, Mrs. Sénadé K. lives in Afagnan with her husband, a schoolteacher. In order to help her husband with the numerous family expenses, she started a business that consists in purchasing palm nuts from farmers, and in reselling them to companies that produce vegetable oil. To bolster her business and grab a fair share of this promising market, she's seeking this loan to increase the quantity of nuts she has to sell. This will ensure her important revenues, which will enable her to provide for the education of her children without much concern.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell palm nuts to be transformed in vegetable oil

loans.name: Basangul

texts.en:
K. Basangul works hard daily to increase the family income so that her children can have a good life. Thanks to her industrious nature, she was able to purchase a small plot of land for her and her husband to farm.  However, the yield has decreased and family expenses are using up the little capital they have. Basangul and her husband have decided to plant onions and potatoes, as these crop are sought throughout the year. 

Basangul is requesting a loan of 1400 Somoni (425 USD), with the hope that she will get through these hard times.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Malap 1 Group

texts.en:
This is Adama K., Sallay K., Sallay K., Fatmata K. and Rugiatu K. of the group Malop I. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Makeni. This is their eighth loan from SMT. With their most recent loan, each of them received 1,000,000 LE. That loan created a meaningful impact in each of their lives. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees, as well as be able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 1,200,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Adama K. (right) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-three years of age and was born in M’Boleh, five miles from Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with six children. Three of her children are in primary school, while one is in secondary school and the other two are not yet of school age. Her husband is a carpenter, making and selling pieces of furniture. Adama sells clothes and local produce at Makambo, a town on the outskirtof Makeni City.

With this new loan, Adama will expand her business. She will be able to buy at least five pieces of laise materials and twenty pieces of cotton. She travels to Freetown, about 390 miles round trip, to buy the goods she sells. In Freetown, a yard of cotton costs her 18,000 LE which she sell in Makeni for 25,000 LE. She buys 8,000 LE a yard of laise in Freetown and and then sells for 10,000 LE.

So far, the only challenge she is facing in her business is that of bad debtors. A bad debtor is someone who is not paying Adama after she supplies them with goods to sell in the marketplace. She is now therefore very careful in selecting the people with whom she conducts business. Apart from this, business is going well for her and she loves doing it. With the profit she makes, Adama can take care of her children when they are sick. It is also easier for her to feed, clothe and educate them.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials

loans.name: Kobiljon

texts.en:
K. Kobiljon has been farming for six years. He owns a small plot of land in Shahrituz, Tajikistan, where he cultivates wheat, potatoes, and onion.  He also raises some livestock. Kobiljon and his wife (pictured in the photo with his mother) have 3 children. Kobiljon does not have a formal education and has very limited reading and writing skills.

With this loan, he will be able to buy much needed seeds and fertilizer.  He believes that his farm will continue to generate profit. He hopes to provide his children with the education he did not have the privilege of receiving himself.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Kponkou Sokémawou

texts.fr: Célibataire sans enfant, Mr K. S. a cinq (05) personnes à charges. Chauffeur de son état, il vit actuellement dans la ville d’Aného. Malgré ses efforts, son métier de chauffeur n’arrive plus à lui procurer de revenus suffisants pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Alors il sollicite ce crédit pour acheter un moulin à piments et tomates pour augmenter son revenu afin de pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Unmarried and without children, Mr. S. K. has five people in his care. A chauffeur, he currently lives in the city of Aného. Despite his efforts, his job driving vehicles is no longer able to bring in enough income to provide for his family. So he is requesting this loan to buy grinder for chili peppers and tomatoes to increase his income. He can then provide for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a machine for grinding tomatoes and chilis

loans.name: Fozia M.hussain Group

texts.en:
Fozia baji is 26 years old and resides in Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house and has been living in it for the past 16 years. She completed eight years of education and is the mother of two sons, ages five and six. Fozia baji embroiders and sews clothes to help with the household expenses. Her husband, M. Hussain, runs a grocery shop near the house. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more groceries for her husband’s grocery shop. 

She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Shahnaz bano baji requests a loan to repair her motorbikes for her motorbike rental business. Ishrat baji requests a loan to buy material (spices and cooking oil) for her food business. Haleema baji requests a loan to buy electric supplies (wires and switch boards) for her electric shop. Sardaran baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Oisifat

texts.ru: Наимова Ойсифат проживает в городе ТУрсун-Заде. Возраст 46 лет. Замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Работает на рынке "Дехкон" города ТУрсун-Заде. Имеет торговую точку , где продает различные промышленные и бытовые товары. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 8 лет. В данный момент планирует увеличить товарооборот , путем получения кредита. Это поможет развивать деятельность , которая приносит ей неплохой доход.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 4 месяцев.
texts.en:
Oisifat N. lives in the city Tursun-zoda. She is 46, married, and has six children. She works in the Dehkon market in Tursun-zoda. She has a shop where she sells various industrial and household goods. She has been doing this work for eight years. Now, she would like to increase sales by taking out a loan. It will help her develop her business, which brings in a comfortable income. She can pay off the loan in four months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Rahimjon

texts.en: K. Rahimjon is 36 years old. He is married and has four children. Rahimjon has always been making his living off the land. He has also decided to rear cows. He comes from a family with an agricultural background and he will share that experience with his children. K. wishes to buy more cattle, with the hope of increasing his income and the well-being of his family. He is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni (1200 USD) for a term of 12 months.

loans.use: to purchase cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Active Group

texts.en:
This is Kadiatu S., Kadiatu S. and Fatu M.. They named their group Active Group. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Makeni. This is the fifth time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Most recently, each one in the group received a loan of 600,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impacts in the lives of these borrowers: they were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees and were also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. They could also add to the daily allowances their husband’s give them for food. Today, they are requesting a loan of 800,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Kadiatu S. (right) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-five years of age. She was born in Kabala in the Koindadugu District, north of Sierra Leone. Marriage brought her to Makeni City where today she is managing her business. She is married with five children. Three of her children are in secondary school and the other two are in primary school. Her husband is a civil servant, working for the Ministry of Agriculture. Kadiatu sells locally produced items like rice, ground nuts and palm oil. She has been in this business for over 15 years now.

With this new loan, Kadiatu will expand her business. She will be able to buy at least 266 pans of ground nuts and 1,000 cups of rice. Kadiatu buys the ground nuts and rice from Kabala, a 180-mile round trip. The fare to and from Kabala is 24,000 LE. In Kabala, a measuring pan of ground nuts costs her 1500 LE. She sells a pan in Makeni at 3000 LE. A cup of rice costs her 4000 LE in Kabala and she sells it at Le 6000 in Makeni.

The only challenge she is facing in her business is the difficulty of getting vehicles to transport her goods from the farming villages where the items are grown to Kabala. Vehicles seldom travel those routes because of bad roads. And the few that do brave the roads often charge higher prices. To Kadiatu and colleagues in the group, an increase in profit means making their lives better. They will be able to take good care of their children, specifically with their educational and nutritional needs, as well as saving for emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase ground nuts and rice for resale

loans.name: Tuychiboy

texts.en: S. Tuychiboy is 32 years old. He is married with two children. Tuychiboy is a farmer and has been working the land for the past five years. His household of six include his parents, whom he is responsible for. He has received a secondary school education.  Farming is his principal business activity and he has been formally trained in this field. For the upcoming season, he will grow wheat, onions, and corn. This requires money he does not have. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 1000 Somoni (300 USD) for a 12 month term to purchase seeds and fertilizer for a successful harvest. The income will allow him to take better care of his children's health, nourishment, and schooling.

loans.use: to purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba Shamardanova lives in the Guba region of Azerbaijan and is the mother of four children.

She started a cattle breeding business ten years ago. Mahbuba is requesting a loan of 970 AZN to purchase two calves.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Comlan Déo

texts.fr: Marié et père de trois enfants, D. Comlan Déo vit à Aného où il a appris le métier de chauffeur. Et comme il n'exerce pas pleinement son métier de chauffeur, il s'est lancé dans le commerce de bois et chevrons de tecks qu’il achète au préalable et les revend aux charpentiers et menuisiers. Pour développer ce commerce qui est prometteur, il sollicite un crédit pour augmenter son stock. Ce qui lui permettra d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaires et de faire face aux charges de sa famille
texts.en:
Married and the father of three, Mr. Comlan Déo D. lives in Aného, where he learned to be a chauffeur. And since he doesn't fully work as a driver, he got started in the commerce of wood and teak roof beams that he buys beforehand and resells to carpenters and cabinet-makers. To develop his promising business, he is requesting this loan to increase his inventory. This will enable him to raise his sales figures and to cope with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell lumber and teak beams

loans.name: Sorry For The Poor Group

texts.en:
This is Santigie M., Thaimu K., Samuel T. and Fatmata B.. They named their group Sorry for the Poor. They are local entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka, about fifteen miles from Makeni City. This is the third time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one of them in the group received a loan of 500,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impacts in the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of Le 800,000.00 each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Santigie (right) is the leader of the group. He is thirty-nine years of age. He was born in Mayolo on the outskirts of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. He is married with four children: two of his children are in primary school and the other two are not yet of school age. His wife is also a businesswoman, and the two work tooth-and-nail to develop their family. Santigie sells personal grooming products like toothpastes and toothbrushes, bars of soap, and vaseline. He also sells watches and other accessories. He has been in this business for over twenty years now.

With this new loan, Santigie will expand on his business. He will be able to buy at least three cartoons of toothpaste, three cartoons of Vaseline and a dozen watches. He often travels to Freetown (390 miles round-trip) to purchase his goods. So far, Santigie is facing no noteworthy challenges in his business. He is doing fine in his business and likes doing it very much. Previous loans helped him in building his house to a greater extent than originally planned. And with this loan, he is sure that he will be able to complete the building process.

loans.use: To purchase personal care items for resale

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.ru: Каршиев Абдухалим житель города ТУрсун-заде. Проживает там вместе со своей семьей. Он женат и имеет троих детей. Работает прессовщиком на заводе "Талко". Имеет средние условия жизни. Хочет получить кредит для личного использования. Ему в данный момент необходимо сделать ремонт дома. Погашать кредит сможет из получаемой заработной платы в течение 12 месцев.
texts.en:
Abduhalim Q. is a resident of the city of Tursunzade, where he lives together with his family. He is married and has three children. Abduhalim works as a press operator in the Talko factory, and makes an average wage. He wants a loan for personal use, as he currently needs to make home repairs. He will be able to repay the loan out of his salary within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home Repairs

loans.name: Hamidan M.ahmad Group

texts.en:
Hamidan baji is a wife of M. and resides in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She is 48 years old and has one daughter who sews to earn a living. Her husband has been running a grocery store for 5 years.. Hamidan baji is a very hardworking woman. She rises at 5 am and goes to cut crops in the field. Hamidan baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy groceries wholesale so her husband will have enough stock to keep up his store.

She is joined in her loan group by three more members. Mumtaz baji and Bashiran baji each request a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shop. Shamim Akhtar baji requests a loan to buy wood for reselling. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Badrieh

texts.en:
Badrieh is a 37-year-old woman who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon, with her husband and their five children. Badrieh owns a clothing shop. She asked for a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua to pay the school tuition of her children. 

Badrieh has been a client of Al Majmoua for a year. She has paid on schedule. She has owner her shop for three years. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Having her shop taught her to be more patient. Her family is growing, which means that their demands and needs are also increasing; that is why she made the decision to work and open her shop.
 
Three years ago, when she decided to open her shop, she had the capital to start her business, but now that her family is bigger, she needs some assets to be able to pay her children's school fees. In the future, she plans to expand her business by renting a bigger shop.

loans.use: Badrieh needs the loan to pay her chilren's school fees

loans.name: Chuma Group

texts.en:
Mengi T., age 34, is married with three children (ages 8, 4 and 2). He also cares for two children of his late brother (ages 16 and 14). He has a butcher business which he started in 1998. He works from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily and is able to make around $333 per month.

In the past, Mengi has taken out five loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the loans to open a general store and the butcher shop. He now hopes for a loan to start building a frame for another general store. Mengi will share this loan with his subgroup members, who have butcher shops and cafes. His subgroup is part of a loan group called Chuma. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture Mengi is the first on the right, standing in a red T-shirt.

loans.use: To build a general store

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: Mariée, Madame Eugénie G. vit dans la ville d’Aného avec son mari et leurs trois enfants. A 54 ans elle a encore la vigueur d’une jeune fille et jouit d’une parfaite santé. Comme activité, elle tient une boutique d'alimentation générale et de vente des articles scolaires, activité à travers laquelle elle dégage un peu de revenu pour aider son mari dans la gestion des charges du ménage. Elle sollicite ce financement pour redynamiser son activité et dégager plus de revenu qui lui permettra de contribuer davantage à l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Eugénie G. is married and lives in the city of Aného with her husband and their three children. At the age of 54, she still has the vigor of a girl and enjoys perfect health. As for her work, she runs a grocery store and sells school supplies, a business from which she derives a little income to assist her husband in managing household expenses. She is applying for financing to reinvigorate her business and to earn more income, which will enable her to help even more with her children's education.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies for her store

loans.name: Shahnaz Kosar Haider Ali Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz Kosar baji is 41 years old and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. Her husband, H. A., runs a grocery shop. Shahnaz baji is a mother of four children: one son and three daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Shahnaz baji is a seamstress with 5 years experience. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to diversify her husband’s grocery stock and increase the items he offers

She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Najma baji requests a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. Pathani baji requests a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Shamshad baji requests a loan to buy woods to resell. Rani baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for grocery shop stock

loans.name: Magbanie Group

texts.en:
This is Yabom Kaprr S., Isatu K., Ramatu K., Thatha K. and Iye T.. They named their group Magbanie, after the village where the group leader was born. They are local entrepreneurs in a village called Massori, about fifteen miles from Makeni City in northern Sierra Leone. This is the second time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previously, each one of them in the group received a loan of 500,000 LE. That loan created meaningful impacts in the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees. They’re also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. Today, they are requesting a loan of 700,000 LE each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Yabom (second from right) is the leader of the group. She is forty years of age. As noted earlier, she was born in Magbanie village. Marriage brought her to Masorie village, where today she is managing her business. She is married with one child. Her child is also married. Her husband serves as a local chief whose duties include arbitrating disputes among members of the community.

Yabom sells local produce like palm oil and pepper. With this new loan, she will expand her business: she will be able to buy an additional ten to fifteen barters (five gallons to a barter) of palm oil to add to her current stock. In the village of Masori, a barter of palm oil cost her 30,000 LE. She will pay a fare of 14,000 LE round-trip to transport herself and the palm oil to Makeni. So far, Yabom faces no serious challenge in her business worth noting. She enjoys what she does for a living.

To Fatmata and colleagues in the group, an increase in profit means making their lives better. They will be able to take care of their children, specifically with their educational and nutritional needs, as well as saving some for emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase palm oil for resale

loans.name: Kokoè

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de sept (07) enfants, Madame Kokoè A. vit avec son mari et leurs enfants. Elle fait le commerce de tissus qu’elle achète et revend. Ce qui lui permet de dégager un peu de revenu  pour contribuer aux charges du ménage. Mais le manque de fonds propre reste son principal problème pour progresser dans cette activité. Elle sollicite donc ce crédit afin de disposer d’un fonds de roulement permanent capable de lui permettre d’exercer convenablement son commerce et de dégager un revenu considérable pour venir plus en aide à son mari.
texts.en:
Marriend and the mother of seven children, Ms. Kokoè A. lives with her husband and their children. She does commerce in fabrics, which she buys and resells. This enables her to earn a little income to help cover household expenses. But the lack of working capital remains her principal problem for making progress. She is therefore requesting this loan in order to have continuous operating funds to enable her to do business appropriately and to earn a considerable income for assisting her husband more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in fabrics

loans.name: Safia Abdul Majeed Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is a wife of A. M. and resides in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a two-room, brick house and has been living in it for the past 16 years. She has no children. Safia baji is a very responsible lady who supports her husband by sewing clothes at home. She charges $2 per suit. Her neighbors come to her house have their clothes sewn. Safia baji’s husband buys seasonal fruits from the fruit market and sells them on his fruit cart. Safia baji is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits for her husband. 

She is joined in her loan group by four more members. Parveen baji requests a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Another Parveen baji and Zahida baji each request a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shamim Akhtar baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more seasonal fruits for reselling

loans.name: Kaneez Sher Ali Group

texts.en:
Kaneez baji is a wife of S. A. and a mother of seven children: five sons and two daughters. Kaneez baji and her husband can barely meet the household expenses, so they cannot afford to send their children to school. But they have a dream to give their children a good future. Kaneez baji performs her duties very efficiently. She does household work and runs a grocery shop. Kaneez baji’s husband has a livestock business. He buys livestock to resell. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. Kaneez baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats) for her husband and to use part of the loan amount to buy groceries for her grocery shop. As their profits increase, they hope to be able to invest in their children's future.

She is joined in her loan group by two more members. Ghafooran baji requests a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Suraiya baji requests a loan to buy woods for her wood selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats) for reselling

loans.name: Akoua Odoumé

texts.fr: Marié et mère d’un enfant, Madame A. Akoua Odoumé vit actuellement avec son mari à Aného où elle mène son activité de commerce de poissons frais et de produits congelés. Aujourd’hui pour faire face à la taille de la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite  ce crédit avec lequel elle va renforcer son commerce. Avec les revenus dégagés, elle pourra améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of a child, Ms. Akoua Odoumé A. currently lives with her husband in Aného, where she does commerce in fresh fish and frozen goods. Today, to cope with how big the customer demand is, she is requesting this loan for bolstering her business. From the income derived, she will be able to improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish shop and frozen goods

loans.name: Upendo K.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Upendo M. from Mbeya. Not yet married, Upendo has been running a business selling women’s and children’s clothes since 2005. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, earning a monthly profit of about $45.

She is now requesting a loan of $575 in order to purchase more clothes in bulk and in the future plans to expand her business. Debora thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Sarah Adjo

texts.fr: Née dans la préfecture de Yoto, madame Adjo Sarah G. est mariée et mère de  sept (07) enfants. Elle vit actuellement avec son mari dans la ville d’Aného. Son activité principale est la vente de mèches et de produits cosmétiques dans son atelier de coiffure. Pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaires et accroître son revenu, elle sollicite ce financement.
texts.en:
Born in the prefecture of Yoto, Mrs. Adjo Sarah G. is a married mother of seven. She currently lives with her husband in the city of Aného. Her main occupation is selling hair extensions and cosmetic products in her hair studio. She is seeking this loan to grow her business and increase her revenues.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to sell hair extensions and cosmetic products

loans.name: Zarnishan

texts.en: Zarnishan H. was born in 1979 and is the mother of two (2) children. She has been in the business of selling bed sheets and linen cloth for the past 6 years. Zarnishan is requesting a loan of 970 AZN to purchase a supply of sheets and linen cloth items to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase bed sheets and linen cloth items

loans.name: Amah

texts.fr: Monsieur A. Amah est né le 12/12/1960 à Lomé. Agriculteur de profession, il est marié et a à sa charge trois personnes. Il est spécialisé dans le maraîchage auquel il associe l’élevage de lapins. Face à l’élargissement de son marché, il envisage agrandir son espace cultivable et son enclos. Ainsi, il sollicite ce crédit qui lui permettra d’arriver à cette fin.
texts.en:
Mr. Amah A. was born on December 12, 1960 in Lomé. A grower by trade, he is married and has three people in his care. His specialty is in market gardening, with which he has included the raising of rabbits. Given the broadening of his market, he envisions expanding his arable land and his fenced area. He is therefore requesting this loan, which will enable him to achieve his goal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To raise rabbits and to grow vegetables for market

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is a 35-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in southern suburbs of Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. Mohamed owns a pick-up from which he sells fruits and vegetables. He has requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to reimburse a loan. It is his fist time that he has asked a loan from Al Majmoua. He promised to pay on schedule.

loans.use: Mohamed needs the loan to reimburse a loan

loans.name: Gloria A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 58-year-old Gloria K. from Mbeya, married with five children between the ages of 25 and 34. Gloria has been running a cash-lending business since January 2008, lending small amounts of cash from $5 to $25 to the people around her, and being repaid with a small amount of interest after a certain period. Working for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week, Gloria currently earns about $45 each moth from her business.

Gloria is currently requesting a loan of $650 in order to lend to more people, and in the future she plans to employ more workers. Gloria thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To lend money to more people

loans.name: Ayélé

texts.fr: Madame Ayélé G. est âgée de 48 ans et vit à Aného. Elle est mariée et a à sa charge six personnes. La vente de légumes frais et condiments de cuisine est son activité principale. A cet effet, elle sollicite un crédit pour faire un stock capable de satisfaire sa clientèle qui devient de plus en plus importante. Des bénéfices, elle pourra subvenir correctement aux besoins des personnes dont elle a la charge.
texts.en:
Ms. Ayélé G. is 48 years old and lives in Aného. She is married and has six people in her care. Selling fresh vegetables and culinary condiments is her main business. For this, she is requesting a loan to build an inventory that is able to meet customer expectations, which is big and growing. From the profits, she will be able to provide appropriately for herself and for those in her care.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell vegetables

loans.name: Fayez

texts.en: Fayez is a 25-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh in souther suburbs of Lebanon. Fayez is a car mechanic. He has asked for a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua to purchase new merchandise and better meet his client’s needs. This is his second loan and the first was handled very well.

loans.use: Fayez needs the loan to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Emilienne

texts.fr: Madame Emilienne L. est née le 29/04/1959 à Aného. Elle a à sa charge deux personnes. La vente du riz en détails et d’huile constitue son activité principale. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour acheter ces produits pour couvrir la demande de ses clients qui devient de plus en plus importante. Les bénéfices qui découleront de la vente lui permettront d'améliorer ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Ms. Emilienne L. was born on April 29, 1959 in Aného and has two persons in her care. Selling rice and vegetable oil retail constitutes her main business. She is applying for this loan to buy goods to meet customer demand, which is increasing more and more. The profit derived from her sales will enable her to improve her living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in rice and vegetable oil

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed is a 52-year-old man who lives in Bourj El Barajneh in souther suburbs of Lebanon. Mohamed works in a sewing factory. He has requested a loan of $500 from Al Majmoua to purchase new merchandise.

loans.use: Mohamed needs the loan to purchase more capital

loans.name: Sonakhanim

texts.en: Sonakhanim D. lives in the town of Khachmaz in Azerbaijan. She is a widow, a kind woman, with two (2) children. She was born in 1966. Sonakhanim is in the business of selling souvenirs and table ware. She is requesting a loan for 970 AZN to purchase supplies of souvenirs and table ware.

loans.use: Purchase souvenirs and table ware

loans.name: Povi

texts.fr: M. Povi est née à Agbodrafo le 21/05/1966. Elle vit actuellement à Aného avec trois (03) personnes à charge. Elle fait le commerce des céréales depuis 13 ans. En période d’abondance elle achète pour les stocker afin de les revendre en saison sèche où les prix augmentent considérablement. Pour cela, elle sollicite un financement pour constituer un stock de maïs et de haricot afin de les revendre plus tard. De la vente, elle tirera des bénéfices lui permettant d'améliorer ses conditions de vie et celles de sa famille.
texts.en:
Povi M. was born in Agbodrafo on 5/21/1966. She currently lives in Aného with three people in her care. She has been in the business of selling grains for 13 years. In fruitful periods, she buys and stocks grains to sell them in the dry season when the prices go up considerably. To do this, she is seeking financing to build up a stock of corn and beans to be able to sell them later. From the sales, she will use the profits to improve her living conditions as well as those of her family.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock up on and sell corn and beans

loans.name: Waaminifu Group

texts.en:
Zainab A., age 32, is single with three children, ages 15,13 and 9. She has a food vending business, which she started three years ago. She works from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. daily and is able to make about $100.

In the past, Zainab has taken four loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to improve the quality and quantity of her food. She has also managed to secure a place where she can sell her food from inside a small room. She hopes for a new loan to buy big quantities of food, such as a 50 kg sack of rice and wheat flour, instead of buying 2 kg every day. Zainab will share this loan with her subgroup members, who sell food and fish and have shops. Her subgroup is part of a loan group called Waaminifu. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.
	
In the picture, Zainab is on the left in a black T-shirt.

loans.use: To buy food in bulk

loans.name: Dosseh

texts.fr: Né à Aného le 24/07/1976, Mr Dosseh D. est marié et père de 3 enfants. Depuis trois ans, il s’est lancé dans la vente  de téléphones portables et de cartes de recharge en gros aux détaillants de la ville d’Aného. Pour faire face à la consommation qui ne cesse d’accroître, il sollicite un financement pour augmenter la quantité de ses commandes. Cela lui permettra d'accroitre considérablement son chiffre d'affaires, ses bénéfices et ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Mr. Dosseh D., born on July 24, 1976, is married and the father of three. Three years ago, he began selling mobile phones and phone cards wholesale to retailers in the city of Aného. To address the ever-growing consumer activity, he is applying for financing to increase the quantity of his orders. This will enable him to improve his sale figures considerably, as well as his profit and living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell mobile phones and phone cards

loans.name: Murad

texts.en: Murad D.  was born in 1986 and is single. He lives in the town of Khachmaz, in Azerbaijan. Murad has been in the taxi business for two (2) years. He is requesting this loan for 600 AZN to purchase spare parts and improve his taxi business.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts

loans.name: Mikocheni B Group

texts.en:
Mourine Z., age 36, is married with three children, ages 14, 10 and 6. She has a boutique clothing shop, which she started two years ago. She works from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $162.

In the past, Mourine has taken out one loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more women's clothes to increase sales. She hopes for a new loan to increase her capital and start sales of vitenge (traditional Swahili fabrics) shirts for men. Mourine will share this loan with her subgroup members, who sell food and chicken and run boutiques. They belong to subgroup B of the Mikocheni group, whose members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Mourine is second from the left in the back row.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma was born in 1966 and she lives in a suburb of Doboj, Bosnia. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a construction worker, but even though he has a steady job, he still does not earn enough to support their family.  As a result, Alma has a vegetable garden and she raises chickens, selling the meat in the local market.  

Alma requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women International that she will use to purchase additional chickens. She hopes the additional income from selling chicken meat will help her to provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To buy chickens.

loans.name: Safida

texts.en:
Safida was born in 1955 and she lives in Pridjel, an agricultural village in Bosnia. She is married and her husband is retired, though he still does seasonal construction work.  

Safida grows vegetables and sells beans and carrots in the market. She recently started raising chickens and has developed a loyal customer base in the market who claim that her eggs are among the best they’ve tried.  

She requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women International that she will use to purchase additional chickens. She will use the additional income from selling eggs to help support her family.

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Marica

texts.en:
Marica was born in 1954 and she lives in a suburb of Bijeljina in Bosnia. She lives with her husband who grows cabbage and sugarcane in the local market.  

Marica takes care of 3 cows and sells the milk to a local milk station. She also has a field in which she grows vegetables, such as corn and potatoes. Next summer, Marica plans to purchase additional cows, and she needs to grow extra corn in preparation for their arrival. 

 She requests a loan for 1,000KM from Women for Women International to buy minerals for her land, on which she plans to start growing the new crops.

loans.use: To buy minerals for farming

loans.name: Xiomara Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Xiomara Mercedes C. Benedit tiene la edad de 38 años, su estado civil es acompañada, Doña Xiomara tiene 3 hijos: una mujer de la edad de 19 años  que cursa recientemente  el  5 año de secundaria, el varón de 7 años que cursa el 2 grado de primaria y su hija mas pequeña de 5 años que cursa el 3 nivel de primaria,  su compañero de vida  no labora, sus propósitos son comprar su propia casa por lo que su situación es difícil quien vive recientemente con su papa ella desea darle todo el apoyo a sus hijos en la formación educacional de ellos por lo que quiere que todos sus hijos estudien tengan un buen porvenir  y es por eso que ella desea luchar porque piensa en sus hijos y así lograra dejarle a sus hijos un lugar donde ellos puedan  vivir cómodamente y que no pasen necesidades en un futuro.


Su actividad económica  es la venta de  mercadería en general  como: ropa interior para damas, perfumes, lociones, crema, ropa para caballero y niños, el tiempo de tener este negocio es de  10 años, la forma en como inicia su negocio es por la necesidad de sacar a sus hijos adelante y al darse cuenta que no encontraba trabajo en su oficio de costurera decide distribuir productos en el departamento de puerto cabezas y otros departamentos y al notar la afluencia de clientes ella decide darle seguimiento, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo que será destinado para  la compra de sus productos por lo que es necesario realizar una serie de compras en la capital de Managua por que le resulta mas factible la compra de estos al por mayor  y dará la satisfacción de los diferentes pedidos de sus clientes razón por la que esta agradecida a la fundación y otras organizaciones por el apoyo brindado en este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Xiomara Mercedes C. Benedit, 38, has three children, ages 19, 7 and 5. Her common-law husband does not have a job. Her long-term goal is to buy her own home; currently she lives at her father's. She would like to give her full support to her children's education, and hopes to give them a comfortable place to live and for them to have a better life. Her business is the sale of general merchandise, such as, ladies underware, perfumes, lotions, creams, men's and children's clothes. She started her business ten years ago; when she could not find work as seamstress, she began selling beauty products, and soon her business grew. The loan Xiomara is requesting will be used as work capital to purchase wholesale products in Managua City, and satisfy her customers' increasing demand. Xiomara is thankful to the Fundacion and to the other organizations that provide financing.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: work capital

loans.name: Vojna

texts.en:
Vojna was born in 1976 and she lives in Bijeljna, a village in Bosnia. She is married and has 9-year old twins – a boy and a girl. Vojna currently runs a collection station for milk in her home, in which local farmers bring her their milk and she sells it in bulk to local milk factories.

Vojna requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women International to purchase a milk transportation vehicle.  She currently relies upon farmers to bring her their milk, but not many have the ability to do so.  With the transportation vehicle, she can drive to visit farmers directly, including many in remote locations. She expects that her milk supply will increase significantly, allowing her to demand higher profit margins from the milk factories.  

Although the milk transportation vehicle cost significantly more than 1,000KM, Vojna has already saved up the bulk of the money needed for the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a milk transportation vehicle.

loans.name: Fuzuli

texts.en: Fuzuli (his brother is pictured here, because Fuzuli was not available when the photo was taken) was born in 1970 and lives in the Azerbaijan town of Khachmaz. Ten years ago, he went into business as a farmer. Now he is married, has one child, and needs a loan of $1,200  to buy seeds pesticides and fertilizer that he can use to improve his farm.

loans.use: to buy seeds, pesticides and fertilizer

loans.name: Slavica

texts.en:
Slavica was born in 1982. At 26, she is unmarried and lives alone in Doboj, a town in Bosnia. She works as a waitress and bartender, earning 450KM/month, the equivalent of roughly $280 USD/month. This is not enough to support her, so she also works at home, offering makeovers and manicures to family, neighbors and friends. She is often able to sell cosmetics to these customers, generating additional income.

Slavica requests a loan of 500KM from Women for Women International to purchase cosmetics. She will use the cosmetics for her makeovers, and also will resell some cosmetics for a profit. She needs this business to meet her basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics that Slavica can resell for profit

loans.name: Mti Pesa Group

texts.en:
Abdulmajid N., age 22, is single without any children. He has a welding business, which he started 2 years ago. He employs three laborers. He works from 7am to 6pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $122.

In the past he has taken out one loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to purchase a machine for charging batteries for his welding tools. He now hopes for a new loan to buy another welding machine. Abdulmajid will share this loan with his loan group, Mti Pesa, which totals 18 members. These members hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

In the picture Abdulmajid is in a red and black t-shirt in the front center.

loans.use: To buy another welding machine for his workshop

loans.name: Sobhieh

texts.en:
Sobhieh is a 57-year-old widow who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon, with her only child. 

Sobhieh owns a small shop where she bakes “markouk,” a traditional Lebanese flatbread. Markouk is a type of thin bread that is baked on a domed or convex metal griddle known as a "saj." It is usually large, about 2 feet long, and thin. Similar to the procedures for making other flatbreads, the dough of saj bread is flattened and kept very thin prior to cooking, resulting in a very slender depth to this bread. 

She has requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise for cooking her bread. She also needs the loan to help her family expenses.

Sobhieh is known for her good quality bread and her low prices. Actually, she is the cheapest in her area. Her shop is well-positioned, because her clients are her neighbors and students, and she is near a school.

When she first started her business, she faced some difficulties because there was a lot of competition between her and other producers of markouk. The competition didn’t allow her to sell as much markouk as she expected, but now she found the solution by lowering her prices.
 
Sobhieh is an active woman. She started her business after her husband's death so that she can support her family and make a living.

loans.use: Sobhieh will use the loan to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Zaur

texts.en: Zaur is single and lives in the Azerbaijan town of Khachmaz. He was born in 1985, and went into business as a farmer five years ago. He is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina O. sells second-hand shoes and bags. She has been in this business for the past three years. She travels once a month to purchase second-hand shoes and bags. Justina needs the loan amount of N99,000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. As the festive season is fast approaching, the demands for her second-hand shoes and bags will increase.

Justina is 34 years old and married to Mr. O., who is a taxi driver. They have two children who are aged 5 and 7 years respectively. She hopes to assist her husband in caring for their children. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence sells foodstuffs like bags of rice. She has been in this business for the past four years.
