Before starting this business, Florence sold second-hand clothes, shoes and bags. However, she changed her business because she believes foodstuffs yield higher profits. Also, the demand to purchase foodstuffs is higher in her community.

Florence needs a loan of N99,000 so she can purchase more bags of rice to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Hope

texts.en:
Hope is an industrious woman who owns a salon. She styles hair for people and also sells styling creams and combs. She has been in this business for the past five years. Apart from this salon business, Hope also owns a tailoring business where she sells tailoring materials and also mends clothes for her customers. Hope needs the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchases a generator to help her cope with electricity problems.

Hope is a LAPO client. Hope is 41 years old and married with two children. She says thank you to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a generator and hair materials

loans.name: Shazia Kosar Shoqat Ali Group

texts.en:
Shazia kosar baji resides in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She is26 years old. Her husband name is S. A. and he has a scrap business. Shazia baji has three children: two boys and one girl. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Shazia baji has been sewing clothes for the past 2 years. People in her community come to her to have their clothes sewn. She saves her earnings for her children’s school fees. Shazia baji has a two-room, brick house where she lives with her children and her brother who is a butcher. Shazia baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy to buy animals (goats) for her brother's meat-selling business. 

She is joined in her loan group by three more members. Naseem baji requests a loan to buy tools for her workshop. Syedan baji requests a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Farzana baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animal stock for butcher business

loans.name: Malaknisa

texts.en: Malaknisa and her husband (who is pictured here because she was away when the photo was taken) are the proud parents of two children. They live in the Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. Malaknisa was born in 1965, and she and her husband have 10 years of experience in farming. They have applied for a loan of $1,200  to buy fertilizer and seeds, which they will use to improve their farming business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Iderea

texts.en:
Iderea O. is 38 years old. She is married with two children.

She has a shop where she sells lace fabrics. She has been in this business for the past five years. She goes to Lagos Island once every week to purchase lace fabrics to sell to her customers.

Iderea needs a loan of N70,000 so she can purchase more lace fabrics to sell. She hopes to be a lace distributor in the future.

She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more lace fabrics to sell

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en: Elijah A. S. is married and supports 7 dependents. He has attended school through senior high school.. Elijah is a mechanic who does repair work and sells spare parts at Kissi near Elmina, Ghana. He has maintained this business since 1996. His wife has a business as a trader. Elijah uses his income to take care of the family's financial needs. Elijah will use the loan to purchase supplies of spare parts to sell. With the new profits from this increased business, he plans to save towards building a house for the family to live in.

loans.use: Purchase additional spare parts for sale.

loans.name: Mujeres Victoriosas Group

texts.es:
hola nosotras somos el grupo Mujeres victoriosas, somos mujeres luchadoras y con muchos deseos de salir adelante, somos vecinas cercanas y con experiencia de varios años en las actividades que realizamos, nuestro grupo se forma de la siguiente manera:
Ana A. soy la coordinadora del grupo tengo 3 años de dedicarme a la elaboracion y venta de comidas, de mi depende mi hija, soy madre soltera.
Doña Martha: ella se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de sopa de mondongoy nacatamales, la sopa de mondongo es una comida muy exquisita de nuestro pais, y se vende muy bien.  Dona Lorena: ella se dedica a la venta de productos vogue, (cosmeticos, cremas etc) ella es madre soltera y es madre de 4 hijos.  Dona Lucidalia: ella vende burritas de carne, frijoles, chirizo y refrescos en un punto de taxis, este es un lugar muy estrategico para la venta de su porducto, ella es viuda. Dona Francisca: ella vende ropa hace 4 años, ella vive sola.
todas necesitamos el credito para sacar adelante nuestros negocios que son la unica fuente de ingresos monetarios que tenemos, necesitamos tener una mayor venta para poder tener mejores gaancias.
texts.en:
Hello, we are a group called "Mujeres victoriosas" (meaning Triumphant Women). We are fighters and we have many hopes of become a success. We are close neighbors and with various years' experience in the businesses that we run. Our group is made up of the following:

Ana A.. I am the coordinator of the gorup and I have 3 years' experience in making and selling foods. My daughter depends on me, I am a single mom.

Martha makes and sells traditional soup "mondongo y nacatamales". The mondongo soup is a very delicious soup native to our country and it sells very well.

Lorena sells vogue products (cosmetics and creams etc.). She is a single mom of 4 children.

Lucidalia sells meat burritos, beans, sausages and drinks at a taxi station. It is a very strategic locale for the sales of her products. She is a widow.

Francisca has been selling clothing for the past 4 years and she lives alone.

We all require a loan for our businesses, our only source of income. We require to sell more to have better earnings.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make foods.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Leyla Mercedes

texts.es:
Su nombre es Ley a Mercedes M. Balmaceda tiene la  edad es de 58 años, su estado civil es casada, su compañero de vida no labora ya que es jubilado y trabajo 14 años al estado, Doña Leyla tiene 9 hijos de los cuales solo un hijo varón de la edad de 28 años depende de ella por lo que el no trabaja pero la asiste en la pulpería que esta ubicada en su casa de habitación que es el barrio de subtiava, Texaco guido 1  cuadra al oeste 2  ½ al norte, los propósitos de Doña Esperanza es obtener su propia casa ya que donde habita recientemente es de una de sus hijas, los deseos que mas predominan en ella son de ayudar a su hijo para que este invierta el dinero en algún negocio y pueda defenderse en el mañana y  así el pueda sobrellevar  la situación del país  por lo que ella se encuentra en una edad avanzada y no puede seguir trabajando de la misma manera que cuando era joven.

Su actividad económica es una pulpería  en donde vende los productos como: sal, azúcar, aceite, jabón y refrescos, el tiempo que lleva en  este negocio es de 4 años, da inicio a este negocio con un  carretón en el que proporcionaba la venta de chancho con yuca y lo realizaba en las calles razón por la que su hija  le propone instalar una pulpería en su casa y así nace el establecimiento, por lo que el financiamiento es para  la capital de trabajo para la compra de sus productos ya que tiene ciertas productos que le gustaría ofrecer a sus clientes y obtendrá ingresos y lograra pagar sus compromisos.
texts.en:
Leyla Mercedes M. Balmaceda, 58, is married. Her husband is retired. Leyla has 9 children; but only her 28-year-old son still lives with her, and helps her run a small grocery store out of their home. Leyla's long-term goal is to have her own home, because the house where she lives now belongs to one of her daughters. She would also like to support her son in starting a business of his own and have a better life, even in the country's economic conditions. She feels that she is growing old and is not able to work as much. Leyla's business is a small grocery store where she sells products such as salt, sugar, oil, soap, and sodas. She started four years ago selling "chancho con yuca" (fried pork marinated in achiote spices with yuca and cabbage salad) on the street. Her daughter suggested to open a corner store in her house, so that she did not need to work on the streets. Leyla is requesting a loan to use as work capital, to purchase a wider variety of products to satisfy her customers' demands and make her profits grow.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: work capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sherifatu

texts.en:
Sherifatu sells wrappers (sarongs). She has been in this business for the past five years. Wrappers are used by Nigerian women to carry babies on the back, and they can also be tied around the waist or tailored in different native styles as skirts and blouses to suit one's taste. Sherifatu carries her wares on her head from place to place and fails to meet the demands of her customer as she can only move around with what she can carry on her head. She needs the loan amount of 70,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell and also pay for the rent of a store. This, she said, would enable her meet the demands of her customers and also help her make more profit.

Sherifatu is 45 years old and married and with three children. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and pay for store

loans.name: Lola

texts.en:
Lola is 37 years old. She is married with two children.

Lola has a store where she sells underwear and nightgowns. She has been in this business for the last five years.

Through her business, she assists her husband in feeding the family and also in paying for the children’s education. In most places in Nigeria, sixty percent of family burden is taken care of by the woman. This trend has compelled most women to be industrious and hardworking lest the family remain in abject poverty.

Lola needs a loan of N70,000 so she can purchase more underwear and nightgowns to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more underwear and nightgowns to sell
